title: Strong, Secure and Safe. text: I sell nail polish online and use 3 different size bubble mailers. When it came time to reorder the 10.5" x 16" size, my regular brand wasn't available. I ordered TOMVYTER. This was my first experience with this brand and I'm more than satisfied.

The bubble mailers were delivered on time and well packaged. They're flexible yet durable and strong. The interior has bubbles for protection, something I obviously need seeing as I'm shipping little glass bottles of nail polish. As promised, they're waterproof and unbelievably hard to tear. (Yes, I did try to rip one and couldn't do so! The adhesive strip provides exceptional protection and stays sealed. I don't have to use any packaging tape over it to be safe.

I've had absolutely NO issues with these mailers, they work beautifully and every bottle of polish I've shipped in them has arrived to its destination in perfect condition. I'll soon need to order more of this size and will order TOMVYTER once again. SO

title: Nice quality. text: I ordered the 'TOPNIKE LED Sign Standoffs 1"×1", Polished Chrome, Green LED Standoff Sign Holder, for Glass, Acrylic and Other Transparent Plates, Pack of 2' via the Vine program and would like to share my thoughts.
First off, I ordered these as a set of green yet as you can see in the attached images, I received white. This was not a huge deal as I plan to use these more as background lights for product photos. There were no instructions with my set but for their intended purpose it's not to hard to figure out how they are supposed to work. The light standoffs are a nice heavy build and the lights are pretty bright. The cable lengths from the light standoffs to the power splitter are only about 2 feet. The power splitter has 6 ports so it is possible to plug 2 more sets into it. From this splitter to the controller you get another 2 feet of cable and from the controller to the wall plug you get another 3'. If you were to use this kit as intended on a wall, these lengths may not work unless you modify and ad more cable. However for my indented use, the cable lengths are just fine.
It would have been nice if these LED lights were RGB however I think you could take a strip of colored plastic film wrapped around the light between the top and standoff base to create a colored lighting effect. This will actually be more effective with the white light. Overall the build quality of these lights is really nice and I think they are of great value for their intended purpose.

text: TAFOMAGIC isn't kidding when they say their adhesive tape dispensers are silent! I sell nail polish online and use a lot of packaging tape. (FYI-this particular brand does not claim to be silent) TAFOMAGIC is not only nice and quiet but starting a new roll of tape is easy and it does a wonderful job sticking to the boxes or bubble mailers I use. The price is a few dollars more than I normally pay for the other brand I've been using but its worth it. title: Excellent desk! text: This table had everything I was looking for! Leg room, the sled legs made it easy to maneuver (this is a MUST!) and the ease of adjustment in setting up and collapsing for storing were smooth and frustration free!

However, I was so disappointed that the height adjustments weren't suitable for my comfort. I've had neck surgery so having a desk at the correct height is essential. Even at it's lowest adjustment height the desk was still too high. I did order another to try, sadly it was also perfect except for it was ALSO too high!

If there was more maneuverability to raise and lower this desk, it would meet all the qualities of a great laptop bed tray desk!

I also noticed the measurements on the description were off by at least a couple of inches. Perhaps I wasn't measuring in the same manner? Anyway, I had to return them but I am still waiting for a LOWER adjustable height setting so I can have the perfect desk laptop tray for my comfort!

No ordinary lapdesk will do, this is the one for me, I need a lower height adjustment so my arms are comfortable and not reaching out and up to type! Keeping the table level is also essential for supporting me while I type.

For instance, say the lowest height from the bed to the table (keeping the table level and not tilted) is 9 inches, if it were able to go lower, down to 6 inches at the lowest height, that's what I'm watching for!

If you work sitting non the floor, couch, or bed THIS table desk tray is sturdy, easy to open and close, it's quality materials are as described. If you're here looking, just order it!

title: Just what I needed ... text: I'm living primarily "paperless" these days -- but there are always a few things that are available only in paper form that I need to keep "just in case," so some sort of a file system is necessary. Because there aren't that many documents involved here, I didn't want to invest in the whole "filing cabinet with dividers and file folders" set-up. I just needed something small that I could tuck away on a shelf in the closet.

After looking at a lot of options (a LOT of options), I settled on this one due to size (perfect) and appearance (I liked the pattern and colors).

It's perfect for my use. I'm using a few hanging folders to hold papers by subject, and regular file folders within the hanging folders to separate sources/etc (e.g., MEDICAL hanging folder subdivided into "Insurance," "Doctor Notices," etc.).

No issues at all -- everything fits perfectly, and I can store it as planned -- on a shelf in the closet.

Would gladly purchase another if I find I need more storage.

title: A top-notch laser all-in-one printer
text: I have had a lot of printers over the years (IBM, Epson, HP, Canon, Lexmark, etc.), and had kind of gone away from HP a bit due to their software/driver problems (when they off-shored the development/support, the quality slipped quite a bit).  However, when printing Christmas cards, my Canon died, and I had been impressed with this HP model when I was helping my sister sort out hers, so I bought one (MFP M479fdw).  Software seems to work reliably so far, so I think HP has addressed that somewhat, granted it is a bit rough and crude in places, but it works.  And it works from both Windows 10 and macOS 11 (Big Sur), as well as from mobile (iOS).  The printer hardware seems to be very good, output arrives quite fast.  One of the problems you run into with cheaper printers (including some lower end HPs) is that they do not put much horsepower into the printer CPUs, and cost-reduce the hardware to the point that they are slow and do not hold up, but this version seems well designed and made.  Ratings from PC Magazine, Wirecutter, etc. generally have this printer at or towards the top, I would say that is accurate.  Print quality on text is excellent, graphics from web pages and similar also excellent, scans are very good (a custom flat-bed would be a tad better, but this is for an all-in-one amongst the best I have seen).  For printing high-quality pictures, you probably still want a Canon or Epson InkJet printer, but this one prints OK for a laser.  HP does not ship this printer with full duty cycle cartridges, but the ones they ship with will still do a decent number of pages.  Control screen is touch and good sized, gets the job done.  Unit is fairly heavy and large, so if you are using this on a desk, check the dimensions some.  The printer is not cheap, but it has excellent print quality and appears to be very well built, so HP has come back to where it once was, at the top.

text: My only criticism of the Avery full sheets sticker paper in beautiful gold is that the backing could use more slices to allow for quicker and cleaner removal after smaller sections are printed.  I think that most people will cut these either by mechanical or scissor/blade methods, and if you make smaller stickers as I've done, you may find that some must be peeled from the edge.  The paper is thick, so with care, destruction can be avoided, and if you are not a perfectionist, you might not mind anyway.  Since I often have problems with Avery templates printing not so perfectly onto precut shapes, I'm more satisfied by cutting my own with a blade after printing.  I've been having fun with these and appreciate the exposure to a full sized sheet of sticker paper.

title: Great planner! text: I love this monthly planner for many reasons.
(1) I like the layout - it just shows each month without any extra details. Thus, the planner thickness is the perfect width.
(2) The front and back cover are waterproof/durable, but not so hard that you can bend them. I'm alright with that because it makes the planner sturdy yet compact and lightweight. Easy to travel with.
(3) The pages themselves are thicker than your average loose leaf paper. I bought fine tipped markers off Amazon to color code my planner and they don't bleed through the pages which is perfect.
(4) I like that it's not just your typical calendar (Jan-Dec). It starts in the middle of the year and goes all through the middle of the next year. That just works for me better.

Overall, I really like this planner! I would definitely recommend it!

title: Sturdy housing - straightforward operation text: Impressive! There's a large list of languages supported and even seems to handle regional dialects to a certain extent. Setup is straightforward and adequately defined in the documentation.

In use, the device seems to perform well. I've just been playing with different settings, including some Russian and Spanish translations - it handled both with accuracy, responding in a clear understandable voice. (It presents both text and voice response)

Structurally, it's very sound. It's smaller than a typical cell phone so it slides comfortably into a purse or pocket. It's housing is a durable metal with a touchscreen display and a simple array of physical buttons (power, home, volume, translate). Fit and finish is top notch. Solid construction, legs are very sturdy and feet slide very easily across the surface. It takes little space when folded. Very comfortable to work on a bed. Very easy to adjust the tilt and height.

BUT, here's why its not a five star. I am a short person (5'3), short arms, legs, torso. At the lowest height (10.6"), while sitting on a bed (no pillowtop or extra height), it is too tall for me. To compensate, I tilt either 12 or 24 degrees to make it more comfortable to type (be sure to use the stopper!) Also, the book stand feels a little flimsy compared to the construction of the desk. Not great, but not good either. And I have to use some force to place it into the slot.

Overall, this was the biggest laptop desk I could find with the best features. Would purchase again.

title: Worked well in multiple usages text: I used half of these tags to mark specific sections in the 1000 page printed US Equestrian Federation rule book - no removal of the ink on the pages when the tabs were switched to different pages. Also, the tabs seem to be holding up pretty well despite being tossed around in a bag full of horse supplies and a riding helmet going in and out of the car to the barn etc.

The second half of the tabs I took to my elderly housebound neighbor and helped her use to mark the pages with her favorite passages in her large print Bible. She was/is delighted with these tabs. She says they are easy to see, easy to turn, make it very easy to find the passages she wants to read and have not damaged the pages in any way at all. That alone makes them worth their slightly high price - I'm going to buy her a complete set for a second Bible she wants to use at church and one to give to a friend at a nursing home. Definately a product worth sharing - a small price for something simple that made an elderly woman happy.

title: Great product
text: I absolutely love this paper. I spray 3 coats of Rust-Oleum clear spray paint on it in thin layers, letting it dry between layers. Once it's done, I soak the paper in water for about 20-30 seconds. While that's soaking, I take some water and wet my surface. When the waterslide 'slides' off the paper, it's ready to be moved to the cup. Once on the cup, I squeegee out all the water under the image, pat it with a paper towel to try to get any water I missed and let it sit overnight. The next day, I spray another clear coat over the image on the cup and epoxy.

title: Solid and Very Functional text: I spend a lot of time working on the computer and as such I spend a lot of time sitting. One problem with this is the lack of exercise I get during the day, but more of a concern to me is the poor circulation because of being seated for long periods of time. I looked to this standing desk to help me with that, and it works well. That said, I have found another use for it that makes it even more useful.

I have the medium-sized standing desk, and it is large enough to handle my laptop as well as my keyboard and mouse. This is all the space I need. With the standing desk raised, there is some room under it for things like speakers, art supplies and a few other things. Obviously, they have to move when the desk is collapsed.

This is a solid desk and it’s made very well. A latch mechanism on the side is used to lift the desk, and a piston as part of the lift mechanism assists in lifting. The piston also resists when collapsing the desk and I found it took some effort to push the desk back down. This is good from a stability point and is a necessary part of the design, but it should be kept in mind - it’s not effortless to open or close, it does require some exertion in both directions.

I found that this desk is a perfect size for a dinner tray, and when set on the floor it works very, very well as a tray table in front of the TV. It’s not an ideal solution, of course, but it does work.

This is a nice standing desk and I am very pleased with it. It’s a good size and it’s made well, and it can server as a tray table in a pinch.

title: Easy as pie to preserve antique family photos text: I wasn't entirely sure what to expect from these self laminating pouches. At 4 x 6 inches, the ones I tried are best suited for photos and small items you want to preserve rather than a diploma type thing. They are actually pretty simple to use after you read the directions - which include little drawings showing each step by the way.

I used them to seal some old photos that we don't have digital copies of and had no problems at all. Just take your time, center the photo, and smooth the top layer slowly and carefully to get a complete & bubble free seal. Pro tip - write any identifying information and dates on the back of the picture first and it'll be preserved for future generations as well. These pouches are a little pricey, but I will be ordering a box or two for some photos from my Grandparents' old albums before it's too late.

text: I am happy with my order of the Jerry's Artarama Artist Mini Utility Knife Blade. This small utility blade was well-packaged and arrived in great condition. I use different knife blades all over the place for different uses and reasons. I've never had a blade that I felt would be okay to carry in my purse before, although I often wish I had one handy when I am out and about. What's different about this knife is that the blade is on a spring, so that you have to apply pressure with your thumb continuously to use it. Once  you release pressure, the blade retracts back into the housing. The blade only protrudes 1cm from the housing. There is a thoughtful key-ring hole on the blade as well, so you can place it on your key-ring or retractable ID badge holder. I'm carrying this in my purse as it's handy to have a tool to open packaging right away instead of waiting until I get home. Now, I can open and toss packaging into the trash straight away before I bring new items into my home to use a blade stored safely inside.  I just put it straight into the recycle bin or trash, and that means less trash I need to gather and toss outside into the bin. I recommend this for adult use only. title: Solid Whiteboard, Right Size text: NOTE: There are two products attached to this listing. I am writing the review for the desktop easel product.

I have had a whiteboard since college, when I bought it to assist me with doing classwork. It’s a large and unwieldy thing and it is certainly not portable. My wife and I have a smaller one on the fridge, but a small, portable whiteboard would come in handy all over the house. I was very interested in this 9”x11” clipboard-size board as it is about the size I have had in mind for a while. It’s an excellent board and I am very pleased with it.

This is a glass board which is a positive and a negative at the same time. On the plus side, it does not scratch or stain like coated fiberboard which is a problem with “normal” whiteboards. On the flip side, glass is susceptible to cracking when dropped and it is heavier than fiberboard.

The glass surface is smooth and ideal for working with dry erase markers. It is basically just straight glass that is painted white on the back side. Writing goes on easy and wipes right off. I have not had this long, but so far there has been no staining and cleaning off residue is very easy.

Though I use this as a clipboard, it is set up with a fold-out back to make it stand on a flat surface. This is handy when I want to set the board up on the kitchen table or other central location in the house. What this board does not have is a hole in the back to make handing the board up on a hook or nail which would have been useful but it’s not necessary. When the board is laid flat, the easel forms a small drawer underneath which is large enough to hold a couple of markers.

I am very pleased with this whiteboard. It’s the size I need, it’s easy to write on and easy to clean off again. It works as a clipboard too.

title: Great Thicker Body Medium Point Pen text: I have enjoyed BIC Velocity 1.6 Bold point pens for several years. Since I am really a fan of the Bold 1.6ers, I decided to try the Medium Point 1.0 Velocity pens. I enjoy it better than thinner pens. I think arthritic or people with nerve damage would find these pens easier to grip. In comparison to the ZEBRA F301 Stainless Steel 0.7mm Fine point these VELOCITY pens are lighter weight.

This is my first experience with this pen and while I like the BOLD more, I really am enjoying writing with this Smooth gliding pen. I write a great deal at work & for pleasure away from work. This 12 Pack will be a nice addition to my Pen Collection. I will be using them everyday. With twelve I can have a few at home, a few at work, and a few in my bag, as well as one or two in the car.

I find myself being able to both write in cursive and easily print with these pens. The retractable point means less accidental ink stains on my clothes, in my bag, on the bed, or the couch's upholstery, or on my hands. I recommend without reservation to people who like writing with a thicker, lighter weight pen. It's a very smooth writing pen exactly what I need daily. I hope you enjoy using these black pens as much as I do.

Too bad it's bedtime I could easily write a few more hours with this pen. Not enjoying tonight's humidity though. I'm putting a few pens in my bag for work right now, as well as taking a couple upstairs. Have a good night - looking forward to using one of these at work tomorrow.

title: we love this dry erase board and markers text: when I ordered this item I thought it would make a fun addition to the refrigerator and we could write down whatever we needed to remember to pick up the next time we head to the grocery store. Instead, my 13 year old saw the board and immediately claimed it for himself. He's now proudly posted it inside his school armoire (where we house his laptop, books, etc) and makes notes to himself about everything from the last day of school to 'test on Friday'. For a kid that HATES writing anything ever... this is quite amazing.

The erase board is small enough it can be used in a student's school locker, or posted in their bedroom - it comes with both magnets that can be attached to the back of the board (assuming it's been placed on a metal surface) or sticky 'tape' so that it can be used on any other surface.

The neon colors really show up beautifully on the board and the ink don't have any offensive odor - atleast not that we've noticed.

Honestly, we bought Cody a white erase board at the beginning of the school year last year and he's never used it but this system makes reminding himself of important events fun :)

title: Would not change a thing. Great function, design and appearance text: This was my first experience with the PraxxisPro brand. I needed an additional upright hand stapler for my home office, so came to my favorite online shopping place to find one.

I was drawn to the copper metallic appearance, which would go nicely with my metallic gold printer. The black base and copper metallic structure is a great combo. Good job designers!

Now to the more important parts - actual function and ergonomic feel.

I don't have super strong hands, and wear a medium glove, so I didn't want something that would take a lot of muscle to use. This stapler fills the bill.

While it was heavier than expected (and I worried it would grow hard to use), that has turned out to be just fine. The stapler sits up perfectly balanced on my desk. It is easy to grab, and stapling is very smooth. I've been using it for a while now and not had any jams or problems. I haven't tested how many layers it can go through. The majority of my stapling needs at home are pretty basic.

Overall, the function has been perfect, it feels great in my hand, has a small desk footprint and looks great. I would definitely recommend this handsome stapler.

title: Smooth writing, but major quality issues.
text: I bought a bunch of these In all the different colors last year and the writing action really is the smoothest ever. However, the body of the pen is unmitigated crap. I have been using these for about a year now and the thread is not holding up against the pressure of the pen when it is in writing mode. The bodies are now falling apart on me, one after another. When I try to screw them back together, they just fall apart again. I find myself saving the insert to use later in whichever of the casings happens to withstand the test of time. However, this means I will have to also be sure to somehow let myself know what color the ink is in the altered pens. I can slide the color-coded silicone sleeve off of the faulty pen and install it on the other, but that will not look so cool, since the top of the pens are also color-coded and so won't end up matching unless I am "lucky" enough to get a working casing that matches the color of the insert. Huge disappointment that this product's body is of such inferior workmanship. I do so love how the pen writes...

title: Has everything and more text: If you're anything like me, you're looking at this because you have no idea where to even start. Or, maybe it's because you know what you want, but you want a simple way to keep it all organized. Lemme tell you, this nifty little book helps with both and more. It has neatly organized sections, tabs for budgets, wedding theme ideas, venues options and final selections, an incredibly long section for guest lists and then another one for a final guest list. It has tips for how things are traditionally done for weddings like who pays for what typically, a section for helping plan the honeymoon- you name it, it's probably got it. Literally even sections where you can put pictures for dresses, centerpieces, themes, etc. that you like.

My fiance and I had no flipping clue where to start, and the planning process is slow going, but this thing was a God send. If you're debating it like "well, but money, and everything in it is something I could plan myself..." Yep. You right. But trust me when I say that it's an incredibly hectic process and this will help you to not leave anything out. Plus it's way cheaper than hiring a planner.

Some pictures for example, and just a small part of it.

title: Economical wired barcode scanner, but a very lacking manual... text: IMPORTANT FACTS:
-----------------------
*This scanner is wired USB connection only. It feels lightweight and cheap, but it gets the job done. I do think the ones with wireless usb receivers, or Bluetooth connection are much more convenient.

* I'm fairly new to barcode scanners. I assumed like other gadgets, you download some sort of software or app to view the codes you've scanned. That is not the case at all. I found out that they work like keyboard inputs. You can open any program on your pc where you can see the blinking cursor, such as word, notepad, excel, etc. Wherever you put the blinking cursor, aka, insertion point, that is where the codes will show up. You can set it up to show up instantaneously the moment you scan, or you can use the scanner in storage mode, then upload everything later.

* Because there are no apps or software to download like with traditional gadgets, all the settings and set-ups are done by scanning barcodes. Netum gives you a little thick manual. Unfortunately, it's thick because it's accommodating many different languages. There are only a few pages for English, and very little barcodes. Each barcode is for a particular setting. The one setting that is very important to me is the ability to remove a certain amount of characters at the start or at the end of the code. For example, when you scan a USPS package, it'll add 9 digits/characters in front of the tracking number that's on your package. These digits are hidden, that's why you don't see them on your package. I then have to manually delete them, which is a hassle. There should be a barcode setting to remove a certain amount of characters at the start or end of a tracking number. This setting is not in the manual, but they do provide an email for you to contact them should you need settings that are not in the manual. I find that very inconvenient. Why not create a complete manual and set it online for us to download?

Overall, for the price you're paying, this is not bad. I'll go 4-Stars!

title: Cute desk organizer text: I bought this to organize the loose paperwork I always have sitting on my desk, this definitely did the trick. I liked the color, which is really true to photos.
My only complaint was the assembly. The item isn’t really sturdy until fully put together so when I was attaching all the pieces some of them would slide undone which was a little annoying.

title: Super convenient, works perfectly, have never had to call tech support. [Updated after one year: slight problems, still love it] text: I wanted this scanner but I was very, very scared by the bad reviews. I have used it many, many times over the course of the last seven months. It has been flawless. [Updated below - it is no longer flawless, but still very happy with it] It is super convenient. You don't have to connect it to a computer. If you have documents to scan and you don't want to start up a computer or sort them, you just wake it up (this takes less than one second) and scan your documents, and deal with them later, at the office or whatever.

The scanner has a small touch screen. It sucks for entering your password for Google Drive or DropBox, but fortunately you only have to do that once. I entered my NeatCloud credentials once and never again. I entered my Google Drive credentials once when I set it up and then a second time after the over-the-air software update. It has never logged me out just because time elapsed or anything like that.

Other than the tiny keyboard which is never used, the touch screen has a nice interface. When you scan something in, the pages pop up. They auto-rotate, even within the same document, so if you scan something with 5 pages landscape and 5 pages portrait, they'll all be correct in the PDF. On the rare occasions that it gets one wrong, you can rotate it before sending to Google Drive. It automatically removes blank pages. If you put in a stack of 10 pages and accidentally tell it "group" or "single documents" when you meant the other one, it lets you change that before sending. It scans double-sided documents very quickly.

I have never used any of the expense report features. Not part of my life or job.

When I first got it I used NeatCloud. It's nice to have the auto-OCR, but the service is ridiculously overpriced. We dropped that at the end of the free trial period and set up Google Drive. Since then, it's been perfect.

Sending one document from NeatCloud to PDF is easy, but trying to do that for multiple documents is not. It was a big hassle to convert documents in NeatCloud to PDF to put in the Google Drive. You can't drag and drop. You can't tell it "download all to PDFs in folders" which is a feature it needs. I would recommend that you never even waste your time with the NeatCloud service.

I see others have had problems with the document feeder. Not me. [Updated below] 90% of the time it pulls everything down correctly on the first try. The other 10% of the time I have to give it a little pat on top and then they all go through perfectly. It does a good job of pulling apart papers even when I have removed a staple and it has those little paper prong-things that happens when you staple and then remove a staple. I keep expecting it to fail but it hasn't yet.

I see others have had problems with scanned documents not showing up. I have not had that problem once, either with NeatCloud or with Google Drive. Hard to say how many total documents I have scanned but my guess is something like 500 files, maybe total 3,000 pages.

The elephant in the room is tech support. The thing has worked perfectly, so I've never called them. [Updated below] I believe everyone who says they suck and I am worried about my rage level if I ever do have to deal with them. Honestly I feel guilty writing a positive review because I hate to let them get away with under-funding customer support, but my experience with the product has never required me to call them.

The bottom line is that the thing is super duper convenient. I knew I should be scanning every important thing at home like I do at work, and I never did it because I didn't want to hassle with it. Now I do scan everything and I have access to my files everywhere because scanning them takes ten seconds and then I throw all the paper in the recycling bin.

*UPDATE

I have now been using the Neat for over a year. I still use it several times per week. I have had some minor problems with it, and tech support has not fixed the problem that I brought to them. That said, I'm still very happy with it and would buy it again. I am leaving everything above even though it's outdated so that the review shows both how well it worked after seven months and after a year.

I have started having problems with the document feeder. For months it worked by just hitting the "scan" button 90% of the time. Now, it works like that 25% of the time, and the other 75% of the time I have to tap the documents to push them down slightly to get the scan started. So far it has only been requiring that one pat; the other documents in the stack get pulled down after the first one goes.

I note that I have started scanning stacks of differently-sized pieces of paper. I'm impressed that I can put in regular letter-size paper plus legal size plus "check stub" 2/3 size all in the main compartment of the scanner, plus receipts in the receipt compartment, and it scans all of them with one press of the button (or one press of the button plus a pat on top). So, overall I'm still impressed with the document feeder. I do have to push the documents down most of the time, but to me that is an acceptable level of functioning. I would not have even listed it among the problems, but others have mentioned it and above I said it didn't happen to me, so I felt like I should include it.

Another minor problem has appeared. When you scan things into Google Drive, it gives them a file name like this: "NeatConnect_03_02_2015_10_49_03" - which is "NeatConnect_month_day_year_hours_minutes_seconds". The time is wrong. It's off by six hours exactly. Has to be set to the wrong time zone, right? So I tried to find the time zone setting and couldn't find anything like that. I emailed Neat tech support from their website. I got an email from a customer support person and he was asking me to check this and that and email him back with more information. I did. I went back and forth with the guy through several emails and I thought he was very helpful. Then, before he ever suggested any kind of fix, he just stopped emailing me. I have now emailed him twice to say "Haven't heard back from you - what should I do?" and I have no response.

So, I'm not completely 100% impressed by the thing any more, but I'm still giving it five stars, because I still love it. It has made a big difference in my life. I know I could get any old scanner and have access to my documents from Google Drive, but the bottom line is that I'm not going to do that. Life at home is too busy for me to be able to turn on the computer, sit down, and scan everything in. But life is not too busy for me to wake up the Neat Connect, drop in the documents, hit "scan," tap them to get them going down into the scanner, and then walk away. That takes me a few seconds even now that I have to give it the little tap. Now my documents are waiting for me in Google Drive whenever I do have time to name them and put them into folders - or even if I never do spend the time to do that.

title: Great pen but remove the plastic cap from the clicker
text: This pen arrived with a plastic cap on the clicker. You can't see this cap easily at all. I couldn't get it to click at all, and I was ready to send it back as defective. I kept trying to screw or unscrew the clicker, then all at once I felt the plastic cap move. It was then that I noticed the cap, removed it, and now the pen clicks just fine. They should either leave the cap off, or provide a note saying to remove it. It was not obvious at all.

title: Could be more user-friendly, but still a solid, versatile machine. text: The printer comes boxed very carefully, and has a number of little safeguards in the machine that need to be removed before use. Getting the machine plugged in, all the parts moving, etc, was simple enough, and I thought the ink process was particularly interesting. The screen guides you through inserting each cartridge, with a carousel-type of thing that forwards to each slot for the different colors of ink. It took another 10 minutes for the machine to clean the printer heads, align the ink, etc, which seemed a bit excessive. Will it do that each time I change the ink?

Getting the printer to work wirelessly with our computers was a little more complicated, and required the disk on both PCs. The disc installs the machine as both a scanner *and* a printer, with software to control the settings of the scanner function. Although it took some time, the printer is now working well on the network with our computers. Printing is fast and the quality looks good. The copier works as expected. The scanner has a few options for output - scan to PC, scan to email, scan to USB, etc. I've been working through all of them, and while they are great features, I will say it's not nearly as intuitive as my HP Envy printer. It's just a clunkier process, though still useful.

The machine itself is larger than most, but still reasonable for desk-top use. The ink is affordable to replace, which is good, since we have four kids in school who will be using it often for papers and such. It'll take me forever to remember it's not a touch screen, but I'll survive. (but honestly - why not a touch screen??) Overall, though I think some of the processes could be more streamlined and user-friendly, this is a solid machine for a variety of moderate to heavy home uses.

title: Does not print clear images text: The seller worked with me to resolve this issue to my satisfaction. Due to this, I have modified my rating to a 4 to reflect the seller's customer service.

I have tried over and over again to get these toner cartridges to print clear images. Every time I print I get the same result...a streaky print. (See image). This happens in color and black and white. I have tried taking the cartridges out and shaking them. I have tried running a cleaning cycle on the printer itself. Everything I have tried ends up not fixing my issues.

I will say that it was pretty easy to change out the chip from the old cartridges to these cartridges. They even came with the tools needed to get the job done.

But with the print quality the way it is...the ease that these were installed really doesn't matter in the end. ..hence my 1 star review.

title: Jaws Grip Well. Magnets No So Much. text: My wife has complained for a while that we’ve used a large number of clothes pins in the kitchen for closing up bags of chips and popcorn. This collection of bag clips seemed like an ideal solution. It’s a good solution though not perfect, the main issue being the weak magnets.

These are brightly colored clips and there are 15 in the set – and every one of them has a unique color. Though this is a colorful set as such, the colors don’t serve too much purpose other than aesthetic appeal. That is, there’s no way to label these without adding a glob of tape. That’s not a criticism in the least, but using a specific color for a specific purpose will take an understanding among members of the household.

Even though these have a small area of contact between the jaws, these grip well and we’ve had no trouble with these keeping even larger bags closed (when we fold or roll the bag decently, of course). These are fine clips for the main purpose they serve.

Where these fail is in the magnets that are supposed to make them suitable for tacking things to a metal surface. The magnets are weak, enough so that much more than a sheet of paper makes these slide down a refrigerator door if there’s nothing in the way to stop them.

These are good bag clips and they work well as bag clips. For holding things to metal surfaces these are less useful because of the relatively weak magnets.

title: Get a jump on tax season--here's a scanner to digitize all your documents in a flash
text: This flatbed scanner is perfect for your tax season needs. you can feed black and white or color documents through it a stack at a time. It will scan one side or both. It comes with fantastic software that converts scanned pages to Word or other office software for editing. You can also save scanned pages as jpg images, tiff images, PDF files, or more. The setup was easy and the software package is great. It's worth the large download. A word of warning--it is a large download. If you have a slow DSL connection, set your computer and do something else for a few hours. You have to download the software and let it update itself before connecting the scanner to the computer. The directions are pretty good, and the scanner is very well packed. That said, be sure you should check not just the top, but also under the document feed lid to make sure you have removed all the blue tape. While primarily a document-feed scanner, it will also scan photos and flat artwork (up to 8.5 x 14") on the flatbed surface. Just lift up the document feeder. If you need to archive personal or office records, this will make your job a lot easier. I may also use it to convert some ancient typed manuscripts into editable files. It will be so much easier than loading one page at a time on a standard flatbed scanner.

title: Versatile Dolly for Moving Groceries, Shipping Boxes, Storage Tubs text: This SAFCO PRODUCTS STOW AWAY DOLLY is one of the best purchases I've ever made on Amazon. I also use it to move indoors the large boxes that FedEx, UPS, and USPS deliver to my front door. And I use it to shift loaded 14-gal. and 18-gal. [[ASIN:B0014CVDA4 Rubbermaid Roughneck]] tubs around my house and garage.

A feature I find particularly useful is the bright yellow, heavy-duty, nylon pull rope. It makes it possible to move boxes (carefully) without strapping them down. It's a bit tricky to control the loaded dolly with just the rope, but you learn quickly enough. A word of caution: the pull rope can be a trip hazard, if you don't pay attention to where you drop it--I learned the hard way!

The dolly is lightweight, and very easy to carry with the built-in handle. It stores standing upright on one end, and takes up little garage space. The 220-lb. capacity is more than adequate for me, because I try to keep shipping boxes and local store purchases under 50 lbs. total weight.

title: 3M/Scotch Tape Gun well made, safer to use, but blades not replaceable, so expensive over time
text: The 3M/Scotch ST-181 tape gun is well made, and has a retractable tape cutting blade which makes it safer to use than most of the cheaper alternatives.  Most tape guns have an exposed blade which is easy to brush against, injuring the user or someone else in the work area (or when you have the tape dispenser stored, between uses), or clothing or packages.  Duck and ULine also have OEM units with retractable blades, but you will have to shop around for those, the 3M/Scotch is much easier to find. The body of the ST-181 unit is steel, as is the cutting area and blade, blade slider and tensioner.  The tape roller is a hard plastic, as is the tape spool (which is adjustable, tension wise) and wiper.  Pushing on the wiper pivots the blade for cutting the tape.  The handle is plastic with a foam cover, it is comfortable, although over time the open foam can collect a bit of dust and dirt, gets greasy, can be hard to clean (a unit with a rubberized handle will generally be better in this regard).  The ST-181 can also use a variety of 3M/Scotch and other brand packaging tapes, the tape is threaded past a retention/tension device, over the roller and past the blade and clear plastic wiper.  You can start taping the box on the side, use the roller across the top, and then push down on the wiper as you go around the edge, this should cut the tape and press it down, with practice this goes all pretty simply.  Turning the small wheel on the tape hub lets you adjust how much tension there is, which is needed for different types of tape.  This works well with 2" wide tape on a 3" cardboard hub, from 3M and others.  Tape is replaceable, and sold in bulk.  There are a couple of tricks to buying this, 3M/Scotch sells it with and without one or two tapes, price those out as frequently with tape will be cheaper than without (which makes no sense, but...).  3M makes a lot of different tapes, it is generally a very good brand.  Shipping tape generally has better adhesion, storage tape holds for longer and is less susceptible to temperature swings.  The kind of caveat on this unit is that the blade is not replaceable, it is held on with two screws, but 3M does not sell replacements, so as the blade dulls with usage, you will have to replace the whole unit.  Normally the safety of the retractable blades and padded handle would make this a good choice for commercial, but the lack of replaceable blades means it should be used more for light office or home only.

title: Keep Track of Things the Old Fashioned Way text: Everything seems to have gone the way of digitization. Calendars and planning are no exception, but I still like traditional planners and I still use them regularly. My other family members feel the same way and I was happy to add this Wisefine Weekly and Monthly Planner to our collection.

I got this planner for my teenager since she told me she wanted a planner for tracking classes, appointments, assignments due, and the like. She likes the layout of the planner and likes that it is double- spiral bound because it makes the pages easy to turn. The fact that it covers 17 months is nice, too, because it is good all the way through the end of next year.

The pages in this planner are thick and with the double spiral binding, they won’t easily get frayed or torn. You can tear out pages if you like, but it takes a good yank. And the added stickers are fun, too. They let you personalize different days of the week/month. And my teenager likes the blank note pages because they are useful for journaling and other miscellaneous needs.

Electronics have taken over our lives. With calendars and planning, I still prefer the paper version and this planner from Wisefine is an excellent one for most any individual. It helps you track events, dates, assignments, your budget and much more and with 17 months of pages, it will keep you covered for a good long time.

title: Easy desktop calculator text: This calculator has large keys and a large easy-to-read screen. It's all one piece. The screen is fixed and doesn't tilt as some similar models do. It should last a long time. It has two power sources, sunlight (even indoor light) and/or a single AAA cell (not included, but easy to get),

It has all the functions you will need (unless you are taking an engineering class). In addition to addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, it has a percent key and even finds square roots. There's a 00 key if you're totalling a column of dollars. If you're eyes aren't what they used to be and you don't want to fumble for your glasses to balance your checking account, this is perfect.It's big enough for easy use, but small and light enough to keep on your desk on in a handy drawer.

Would make a thoughtful gift for an older relative or friend who still takes care of business or someone who sells at outdoor events in the summer.

title: Nice for Storing Groups of Files text: I have to keep track of groups of papers in a year's time for school and sometimes it can be a bit difficult to do with traditional file folders. title: No USB connection necessary! text: I had the opportunity to order and review the new HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 All-in-One Wireless Printer, with Smart Tasks. My past experience with HP products has led me to stay clear from them because of all the bloatware software that is (in my experience) buggy. With that said, I would like to share my thoughts on this printer.

First off I would like to say that I am extremely pleased with the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025. Just the fact that you can set it up without having to connect it to your computer via USB cable first, was huge! My last HP Printer and Software was so buggy and would lose connection randomly until I moved it from it’s remote location and re-connected it to the computer via the USB cable. Then I would have to move it again to it’s remote location. Needless to say that was very annoying. The 8025 was super easy to set up via WiFi and start using right away with zero issues.

Setting up the WiFi was quite easy with the touchscreen and I never had to make any physical connection to the PC via USB cable. This makes me very happy! Setting up the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 for my Windows 10 PC, Android mobile device and Chromebook was an absolute breeze. For Windows 10 you need only to install the free App from the Windows App Store (without all the unnecessary Bloatware). The Android device was just as simple as downloading the App from the play store. Setting up to print from my Chromebook was as easy as making sure that I was connected to the same WiFi Network and searching for printers via the printer settings on the Chromebook, then add the HP 8025.

At first set up, I did have some issues with the printer to where it would pull through several sheets of paper every time it would print test pages. This was a huge disappointment, however this issue has seemed to correct itself and it has not happened since but I thought it was worth mentioning. It totally could have been user error on my part when placing a small stack of paper into the paper tray for the initial set up process.

This printer has the capability to connect to your Google Drive and DropBox accounts (via the included “Apps” settings) so that you may print FROM them and Copy/Scan TO them. This was “fairly” easy to set up to my Google Drive account but I have yet to try DropBox as I don’t use that as often. This feature alone will make it so much more convenient for my daughter who uses Google Drive exclusively for her School Homework.

You can also send copies/scans from the printer, to email addresses. This is a little cumbersome through the small touchscreen but I do love this feature. Speaking of the small touchscreen - it will prove challenging for those with long fingernails but it is doable ;)

I also tested out the FAX feature that is included with the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 and although this is a dying technology, it’s still used by many businesses as I have found. I am happy to report that the FAX feature works great, and though I won’t use it a lot, I am grateful that HP included this feature with this model.

The 8025 also has included "Smart Tasks" which basically allows you to set up (via the mobile app) tasks such as scanning a document and print directly to your Printer or send to Google Drive, DropBox, OneDrive, Box, Evernote, Quickbooks or an e-mail address. I use this feature currently to scan received invoices from my Android device and send directly to my Google Drive. It places this scan into a designated folder under another folder called "HP Smart". You can create several different "tasks" on the Mobile App to simplify things that you would do on a regular basis. This is an incredibly simple and useful feature that I will be using more often.

In conclusion HP has changed my views with this printer, and I highly recommend the OfficeJet 8025 for those in need of a compact All-in-One Wireless Copy/Scan/FAX Printer

title: Lightweight Feel, but Good Cuts
text: This does not have the feel of a rugged tool, but it does seem very effective and cutting and scoring paper.  I have to admit that I don't have much hope for a long run with this.  The plastic is light and seems a little cheap, but the feel of the blade cutting through the paper is satisfying, clean and easy to use.  I love how easy it is to line up pages and cut squarely.  But again, I just don't think it has a the power to cut through many pages at once or over the years.  But for what it is, I'm impressed with its functionality.

title: Thin Wallet
text: This is really more like an ID holder with a couple of slots than a wallet. In fact, it's almost identical to what I use to hold my work ID in every day. Which technically, could be used as a wallet, but it's so thin, that it's a bit difficult to get cards in and out and of the slots. There are 3 slots on the back. Whatever you slide in there needs to be thin. You can't put in 3 bank card type items because of the thickness. Plus whatever you put in the lower slot will hang out over the middle and top slots if it's a standard business card sized item. I prefer a tiered look, so I haven't been putting anything in the lower slot. The material feels plastic, but it does smell like leather. The cord is really thin, but so far it's been adequate. I like the RFID feature, but I can't really test that out. Overall, it's okay. It will work if you really don't have much to carry around and you just want to use it for your ID, a bank card, & a little bit of cash, but if you have more than that to carry around, you're probably going to want something a little bigger.

title: Wow!
text: This desk is huge! I ordered the extra large because I’m not a small person and I was worried about leg room and fit. There is plenty of leg room and the top is large enough to hold all of my needs easily. The book holder was a little tricky to get into the slot but it worked. If you’re using the book holder in the slot and a laptop it will be behind the screen but the book holder has legs like a kickstand so you can put it to the side and not in the slot. The drawer is great for pens and to hold the piece that keeps laptop from sliding in the slanted position. Everything has a place and folds up nicely. The work space is huge and the whole thing is very sturdy with a quality feel. Another review said the only thing missing would be a slide out cup holder and I agree! It is everything I wanted! I highly recommend it.

title: Easy to use
text: This item was very easy to assemble... just place the top of the shredder on and plug it in. It's also easy to use... you just turn the switch to on. It shreds up to 8 sheets of paper, cards, and cd's. It has a lot of storage space. It has a lot of storage for the material also. I shredded as much paper to fill a bathroom sized garbage can and a half and it's only about half full. Also, the paper is shredded very finely so I'm sure that also accounts for the storage space. I shredded an old ID card of mine and it had no problems shredding it. I also shredded cardstock paper and some thicker laminate paper and the shredder worked fine. It also has wheels on it, making it easier to move. The front of the shredder comes off by just pulling it a little and looks like a small garbage can, so that you can empty it. I still have yet to try shredding a CD. I will update when I do so.

title: A moſt joyleſs fate
text: Oft I haue dreamt of ſuch an inſtrumente wiþ which to adorn my faire maidenhood. As ſoon as I ſaw þeſe moſt curious trinkets, þe need to poſseſs ſuch a beautiful inſtrumente was moſt preſsing. I beſought Faþer ſome coin for which to buy bread at þe market, and tarried not as I went þiþer and purchaſed þeſe wares inſtead, þinking myſelf a cleuer imppe. As I attempted to make þem of vſe, I ſaw þat my hands were vncomely for a gentle and noble woman and I wept in deſpaire wiþ þe knowledge þat I would neuer know þe loue of a kind and noble lord or knight wiþ loaþſsome hands ſuch as þeſe. I was beſet wiþ woe and ſorrow and erewhile I am but a lowly ſeruent wench in an ale houſe, curſed ſtill by þe gods, who haue ſeen fitte to liken my fingers to þe gnarled branchs of a wizened tree. I have ſiþence returned þe "BIC Criſtal For Her Balle Pennes" and ſuffered my joyleſs fate. Perchance a more ſightly lady of grace will find þeſe to her likeing.

title: Very nice phone with great features text: The Pros

* Light and sleek design
* The ability to retrieve messages from each handset. With other, older V-Tech models, I've had to go to the base station voice recorder to do this.
* The ability to switch calls between handsets and to conference call with multiple handsets. Past V-Tech phones I've owned didn't allow this. If you were on a call and another handset was switched on, the call would terminate.
* Small base station voice recorder takes up very little space

The cons

* Sound quality of speaker phone could be better. It sounds tinnier than past V-Tech phones I've owned. The sound is a bit garbled at times too.
* No belt clip. Having a belt clip frees up both hands while talking.
* Flat buttons. This is a trivial point, but worth mentioning for some prospective buyers. The flat buttons offer a nice sleek look, but they inhibit touch dialing. The "5" button has a raised nib to help you detect your fingers position on the keypad, but the flat buttons are still less tactile and effective for touch dialing.
* This model is almost the exact size and shape as my Logitech remote control. Because of this, I often pickup the wrong device when looking for it bu touch. This really isn't V-Tech's fault - it's more of a personal quip.

title: Brilliant Colors, Highly Pigmented, Handy To Use, And No Caps To Lose! text: One of the things I like to do when correcting papers or making notes that I want to stand out is have a selection of nice different colored pens that have different colored ink in them.

WHAT ARE THESE PENS LIKE?
These click pens are covered over half of the barrel in a soft grippy plastic that indicates what color ink is inside the pen. The front of the pen has a clear plastic front on it which is tinted with that same color but is see through. The ink itself is very bright and pigmented. The ink tube inside is filled about halfway up the pen, but is larger around than most ball point pens. There is a plastic tip on the pen to keep the ink from flowing when you first get it, so you have to remove it with your fingernail or something similar.

HOW DO THESE PENS WORK?
The pens are surprisingly smooth and write very well. There is enough drag so that I don't feel as if I am losing control of the pen, but not so much that it is hard to write with. The ink does not seem to blob up much when using, but I did notice that if you hit the writing just right, it will smear a tiny bit. It is not that bad, however, and I would not say it is a big problem. The colors are all very brilliant and heavily pigmented, making these look like the perfect marriage between ball point pen and gel pen.

WHAT I LIKE ABOUT THESE PENS
-colors are all brilliant
-smooth to write with
-grip well any spot on the pen
-don't roll off a desk
-no caps to lose

WHAT I DON'T LIKE ABOUT THESE PENS
-ink should be filled up a bit more
-tiny bit of smearing if hand runs over just right

THE BOTTOM LINE
If you want a nice pigmented pen in brilliant colors that is easy to use, this click pen is a great choice. Although it smears slightly from time to time, in general, it is an easy pen to use and pretty classy looking. The inks are all pigmented and the purple especially is dark enough to be used for general writing when blue or black is usually preferred.

For the price of these pens I have rated them four stars due to the slight smearing from time to time and the ink not being as full as I would like to see. I would rather rate them four and a half stars if I could, however.

title: Spot on text: Works like a charm - make sure that the touching edge of the card is absolutely straight, less you want it to end crooked (because if you flush a crooked edge to the end of the laminate, obviously the card will end crooked in the plastic too.

title: Nice quality for the price, good company that stands behind their product
text: I picked this up while it was on sale, felt that I got a good deal on it. Great value for a functional fountain pen. Mine is a wet write, nib is not as smooth as my higher end pens, but is better than expected. The size is a bit small, but I prefer smaller pens (Sailor Sapparo / Pelikan 200-400 series). I have a few Cross pens and have only had an issue with one of them (A century II with 18k nib). I sent it to Cross and they repaired it, writes beautifully now. The customer service was very impressive, and although my Cross pens are always not my favorites, they stand behind their product and it gave me the confidence to purchase several more (2 Apogees which are very nice, and now 2 Baileys). I bought this Bailey to have as a knock around pen, that I wouldn't have to worry about scratching / breaking. So more of a daily note taker for me. I've only filled it once at this point, so the ink I am using may just be a thin ink. I would prefer a fine nib option on this if it continues to write so wet. It does come with two ink cartridges, but does NOT come with a converter. If you prefer to use bottles inks, you will need to purchase the screw in type converter (the one that works with the Apogee), not the push in.

title: My all-time FAVORITE mechanical pencil! text: After over 30 years in the computer business, I retired and became a full-time student. Now in grad school studying music, I go through a LOT of "lead" taking notes in class, jotting down music, etc. I need something with a good eraser, sturdy enough to withstand my typical day on the bus and running around campus.

This pencil delivers! It's slim enough to slip into the spiral wire of my class notebooks, sturdy enough to survive getting "lost" in my book bag, and very comfortable to use for note-taking, with a cushioned rubber grip. The eraser is nice and long, too, and erases without leaving any marks, important when you're dealing with music manuscript paper. As long as these are on the market, I'll be buying them.

title: A Colored Pencil, Charcoal Pencil and Graphite Pencil Artist's Best Friend. text: The point, oh the point. The point this bad boy gives your pencils turns them into literal spears...the lead point is so long! And the point gets SUPER sharp so you can get some of the FINEST DETAIL into your work. A fine point is actually the 'secret' of many artists today....the finer you can get the point, the more precise every square inch of your work will be. You want your tools working to the best of their advantage and this sharpener will make all your favorite tools do just that. It uses a USB to charge, which is convenient since I always have my computer nearby and can charge it up when I take food breaks.

NOTE: THIS WILL EAT CONTE PASTEL PENCILS AS THEY ARE TOO SOFT. The photos attached show Primo Charcoal Pencils and the difference of a regularly sharpened Berol Prismacolor pencil and one using this sharpener.

title: greatly reduces all the aches & pains from tailbone pressure; works great on my computer chair text: This Luckylife gel seat cushion measures roughly 17" x 17" x 1"

I am a bigger person, and it seems appropriate to my size and needs. I use it on my office chair, where I am always wishing for a little more cushioning. My chair aggravates my back, and while I use a back cushion, it was dawning on me that a little support in the bum area would provide better care. I did try a seat cushion, but it was too thick and firm. It changed the way my chair worked, and I found that I rarely used it. When this cushion came up as an option, the information in in the product description as well as the overall look intrigued me.

The cushion is thin but dense. If you really needed a thicker cushion but still made of this material, I would just buy a second one and double up. The material used, TPE(ultra-flex polymer) is neat. It is a jelly like material in shape of honeycombs. The pad has a zip on cover that has little nubs on one side to help grip whatever you are using it on. Basically less likely to slide of your chair.

I didn't notice any major changes right away. Well, I noticed that it was comfortable to sit on and that it seemed to form to my body. It was after using it for a few days and being at my computer for long periods of time that I realized that I wasn't feeling the usual odd aches in my legs, hip, back. My back wasn't aching as I get out of my chair. So while I have only been using it for a week, it has been a good week.

So depending on your needs.. this might be good for you. If you need a more firm pad, look elsewhere. This is super flexible, and super squishy. I am not sure how it is working, but at least for my needs it seems to be helping. I think the too frim pads (or lack of pad) exacerbate an easily pinched nerve. This seems to cradle my body and alleviate the tension.

Also, it is somehow cool feeling. Not sure if is actually cool, or if it is the design (honeycomb) which may allow for more air flow?

The cover is super thin yet durable.

I read another review that said theirs stunk. I hadn't noticed anything, but I decided to pick it up and take a whiff. There is a faint, unpleasant odor. If it were strong, I imagine it would be unusable. But for mine, I didn't notice it until I sniffed for it.

Like I said, this pad happens to be working for my needs, in my computer chair. I would consider taking it to restaurants as most of the chairs offered really hurt my back (which stems from pressure on butt/tailbone area). Since this is lightweight and flexible, I think it could easily be carried in a large purse, or simply as it. Be comfortable where you can!

I am giving it a solid 4/4.5 star rating. It's still early on in my use, but I am enjoying it so far. It has been great to use. I hope it holds up and continues to be good for my tailbone. I think it is worth the try.

title: An easy to use method of transferring old photos, slides or evdn negatives into digital images text: I thought this would be a basic scanner, configured for sliding photos in... which it is. But when i started playing with it, I learned a few more things. First, the "backer" for holding the photos in place does have little "L" brackets that snap into place depending on the size of your photo. (It supports sizes up to 6 x 8 inch). Theres a small screen to show what you're about to capture and a simple scan and save captures the photo to an SD card. That, of course, can easily be transfered to your computer for saving, sharing, whatever.

One thing that didn't occur to me... Many years ago, when I was taking a lot of 35 mm pictures, I would save the negatives... didn't know why, just seemed like the thing to do. But what can you do with them now? This unit will handle them. Theres a plastic slide tray made just for these old negatives - you place the strip inside and snap it closed, then slide in from the side and capture those shots as photos! (Not just as the negative of a photo) Nice!

As for picture quality, its pretty good - they do offer 2 resolutions and theres some provision for adjustments built it, but that seems a little tedious. Once in my computer, I'll be able to do a better job of "fixing" old faded images with software, anyway.

title: Sturdy, Accurate, and Priced Well text: I have needed a straight-edge for my home office for a while and I have always needed to hunt one down when I need to use one. I have wanted one of these triangular rulers for a while, not just for the cool factor but more for the stability. So far I am pleased with this one.

One of the things that I have been burned by in the past was inaccurate scales. I had one tape measure that supposedly measured in inches but the measurement was off, such that it measured 6" where all other rulers and tape measures showed 5". As such, I always check these for accuracy as a result. This ruler is accurate - 1" is actually 1" and not something else.

For my typical use, though, the ability to measure is not as important is it is to get straight, clean lines. This straight edge does a fine job for me and right out of the package is clean and pristine. Being aluminum I expect it to hold an edge indefinitely, though it is susceptible to nicks and dents if not careful with it. The shape gives me more control over the ruler so it is less likely to slide.

I like with weight, too. It is a little more hefty than a plastic or wooden ruler but it is still very lightweight and easy to handle.

I am happy with this ruler. It meets my need and it is scaled accurately. It's very well-priced too which is an added bonus.

title: Beautiful Brilliant Colors, Fine Tips, and an Easy-to-Use Storage Case text: It's easy to find just the pen you are looking for in this beautiful set. All of the colors are different. (Bright, but not opaque, they are intended for use on white or light-colored surfaces.)

There are lots of articles online about bullet journalling. Starting out as a planning aid, these journals have evolved into illustrated diaries on gridded paper and in some cases, artists' books. That's where these gorgeous pens come into play. They are fine enough to write and draw with. They can also be used with stencils or combine with stamped designs.

If you travel light and are an artist, pack a few of your favorite colors with a pocket sketchbook for notes or handmade postcards. They are great for sketching, greeting cards, adult coloring books, mandalas, and more. If you need a new hobby, try bullet journalling.

There are online groups where you can make friends. All you need is some grid paper and this set to get started. (If you are buying gifts now for the holidays, this would be great for a favorite friend, relative, or crafty high school student.)

title: A great buy! Pretty and a lot less expensive than the plain white ‘name’ brands!
text: 150 Very pretty napkins for about $9.00! This is a great deal and too good to pass on! I have always bought the plain white ‘name’ brands, like Bounty or Vanity Fair, etc., in a Walgreens, CVS, or another regular store. They usually cost about $5.00 +/- for a pack of 50 napkins. With these, the price is much less and you also get colorful napkins that are perfect for the kitchen. You would think that the quality would be compromised for being so cheap, but it's not. I have been using the same one now for several days and it's still not ready for the garbage! Granted, I haven't used it to eat a messy dinner, but it works well for my coffee, tea, and other beverages, and protects my white Corian kitchen counters and wood table. Even if you wanted to use these for a sloppy meal, so what? - they are so inexpensive that it's not a shame to throw them out. The pattern is on the 4 sides that show when the napkins are open, and the other side is plain white. These aren't the softest around, but would still be ok to wipe your mouth. The pack of 150 came in 2 plastic-wrapped packs of 75 in each. None of them were damaged or wrinkled, like some others are when you get them off the shelf in a regular store! To me, that says a lot about the care and quality control by the manufacturer. I have some of these in a holder on the kitchen table, which looks much better than the pure white ones (I used to keep those in a cabinet or drawer! I would definitely recommend these to anyone who is looking for these colors. They are even appropriate for a party or other occasions. I am the first person to write a review, even though the little bit they have were all 5*’s. *** Since I buy items that are not familiar to me on Amazon based on the reviews of others, if you find this to be helpful please mark it as such for future reference, thanks!

text: The materials and workmanship are first rate. If the cap to your pen doesn't screw on, you'll have difficulty getting the pen out of this case. When.you pull on the cap, the cap comes out and the rest of the pen stays behind. I have 3 of these in different colors- the worst is described as "thick" leather. The thicker leather is stiffer and therefore tighter. The one with a thinner softer leather is more workable. Still a problem, but not as much. Might want to consider buying a version designed for 2 pens, then use it for one. Otherwise, a very nice pen case.

title: Good; could be great. text: The shredder works great. As someone who works in an office, we outsource most of our large documents for shredding, but keep little docs here for personal shredding. Now that I can have one at home, it's much more convenient.

I hate having my name and address on papers that I won't keep, so having a shredder comes in handy. This Amazon Basics seems well built and has lasted me quite a while thus far. I haven't had to clean it yet, though the only issue I have is that it can take less papers than the ones we have in the office. I have to make sure the papers are straightly aligned, and since the shredder's in a corner it can be a wee bit difficult sometimes to make sure all edges are straight.

Otherwise, it's fine. Amazon seems to know what they're doing with their Basics line, so I've no complaints other than the straight edges.

title: Fast printing workhorse at a budget-friendly price. - Read toner lock quick fix text: I'm not going to lie, we have to replace this printer every 15 months or so after it has printed nearly a half million sheets of paper. Things start to get a little wonky once we get past the 400,000-page mark, However, we stay loyal because it prints super fast (nearly 1 sheet per second), it's compact, and we have an extra print tray, so, it's cost-effective. We always have extra toner cartridges/drums and this wifi printer installs quickly on all of our Mac/PC computers.
With two thriving eCommerce sites, we rely on this compact business/consumer-grade laser printer every day of the week for our shipping labels, packing slips, invoices and office documents. We cannot afford to have an unreliable printer and the HL-L6200DW series has performed well with heavy use. I also use an HP laser printer at home and according to the reviews, it has about the same lifespan, at a much higher price. Thank goodness my home office needs aren't as demanding and in all honesty, I think the two manufacturers are about the same in performance, longevity and print quality and speed. I like the HP software somewhat better, but I don't think it is worth the extra $100+ for a printer of equal quality.

Toner Lock Bypass:
Open the toner access door on your printer.
• Press the Secure and Cancel buttons at the same time.
• Use the arrow buttons to select the correct toner yield of the toner you are using
TNR-STR = Starter cartridge
TNR-STD = TN-820 standard yield
TNR-HC = TN-850 high yield
TNR-S.HC = TN-880 super high yield

It's a fast printing workhorse at a budget-friendly price.

title: Nice looking, but not so comfortable to use ... text: If you want a stylish very nice-looking pen to use only occasionally (to sign a check, etc.), this might be a great option for you. But if you want a pen that you can use daily for extended periods (writing in a journal, taking notes in class, etc.), yeah, not such a good choice.

The pen has no ergonomic features -- the barrel is smooth (no "grip," no textured area, etc.), which means that your hand will slide down the pen if using it for longer than 15 minutes or so. So you either have to keep repositioning the pen or grip it tighter, neither of which is a great option. I realize that adding even some thin rubber "grip lines" would likely spoil the sleek design, and maybe the target demographic for this pen is the "very occasional use" folks. But bear in mind that if you need a pen that will hold up to lots of use without causing your hand to cramp, this probably isn't the best alternative.

That said, it's a very nice looking pen in a nice presentation box, and would make a great gift (maybe graduation?). I give it 4 stars (I like it -- but only for LIMITED use).

title: I Use These For Essential Oil Roller Bottle Labels text: When it comes to labels, I have decided it is not worth my time to label my essential oils unless I can see them from a distance. Otherwise they look too much alike. Let's see how these worked out.

WHAT ARE THESE LIKE?
These labels come in a box dispenser. They come out in a roll and they can be removed one at a time and the others are protected in the box.

HOW DO I USE THESE?
I use these mainly to cut into fourths and label essential oil roller bottles with. I then label them in permanent ink and use packaging tape to wrap on top of it as it protects it from some of the oil.

HOW ELSE CAN THESE BE USED?
These can be used on file folders, papers, boxes, and even shelves. If you plan to use these on plastic boxes, be sure to put a piece of packaging tape over top of them to be sure they stick and are protected.

ARE THEY EASY TO WRITE ON?
I use a Sharpie or other permanent marker with a point and they seem to do very well with these. Not a lot of bleeding or issues.

DO THEY WORK WELL AS A LABEL?
On paper they work great and don't need help to stick. On more slick surfaces like plastic and glass, I put the piece of packaging tape over top. You can still read it and it is protected and stays in place.

THE BOTTOM LINE
These stickers are easy to see, are easy to dispense, and are easy to use for me on roller bottles. They have many uses, and in some cases might need a piece of packaging tape (see through) over top just to keep them in place if you are not sure.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. These are just what I needed and the perfect size for me. I will probably blow through this box pretty quickly and would not be opposed to buying another one in the future.

title: Very nice and sturdy printer stand with a neutral color scheme... text: THE GOOD:
--------------
* Easy to assemble.
* Sturdy once assembled.
* Wood panels finished nicely and are smooth.
* Two tier and adjustable. Make your measurements first though, then set the shelves.
* Overall dimensions are about 12x17x16 inches.

THE BAD:
-----------
* A little QC issue. One of the inserts for the levelers came completely out. The leveler wouldn't screw in, so as I reversed it, it took out the internal insert with it. LOL! I used pliers to hold the insert in place, as I unthread the leveler. Then I re-installed the insert, and reinforced it with glue.
* Adjustable here doesn't mean on the fly. That's why I said above, "make your measurements first..." You would have to unthread some screws, then rethread to make adjustments.

Overall, I'll give this stand 4-Stars, would be 5 if not for the QC issue.

title: Perfect for your High School Student - Not for your college bound young adult text: The thing weighs 2 pounds. The wire spiral is durable enough to last the first half of the school year. The cover is a thick plastic and the back cover is cardboard. The best thing are the dividers have reinforced pockets on each side. It's perfect for high school where the student can't go to their locker between classes, the one notebook has all classes neatly separated and easily accessible. We would always get a new notebook after the winter/Christmas break.

Only suggestion to the manufacturer would be to double the paper thickness and halve the number of pages - heavy ball point pens can bleed through as it is today.

Now that he is in college he has a seperate notebook for each class, making his or her load lighter and the potential for losing all his notes when he misplaces his notebook is reduced 80 percent - lol. Looking back we sent our young man off to freshman year in Orange & Red, Sophomore year was Green & Blue, Junior year Orange & Green, Senior Year was Black & White.

My second impression came from the weight. The notebook is heavy. Unless a student needs to take notes on five projects in one class or has no time between classes, the notebook is probably heavier than most students would want to carry. When more and more teachers are using on-line notes and projects, I'm not sure who might find this notebook useful.
