There was space for a couple more. Large bin is large enough that I think you could overload it. I haven’t had fantastic luck with the style of adhesive, but I’m giving it another chance. So far, so good. I will update if it falls off.

title: Stable bed table - easy adjustment for height and angle. text: I really like this bed table. Its fully adjustable with multiple heights and multiple angles. It has slots for phones or tablets and an accessory book stand that's stored underneath for quick access. Pull from the bottom, position in a slot on top.

Theres cam locks to adjust leg height and angle... and even a small accessory drawer. Everything functions smoothly, and best of all, its sturdy. This would be great for most any kind of bed table need... writing, drawing, or just working on a laptop.

Its designed primarily for bed use, and works well on a sofa. But the legs spread to about 23.5 inches at their lowest height. Not quite narrow enough for my overstuffed recliner, but I've discovered the sled like legs can slide in under the arm cushions and remain stable in my recliner. So it even works there. Nice!

title: Interactive Instructional Handwriting Program text: Learning to Print has never been this fun. With a musical journey through an Alphabet House DVD and a book with erasable pens, children are quickly able to learn how to print. The companion website also has fun playtime activities and a birthday club. The pens are specially designed with the eraser on one end and they are in a special case attached to the book. This provides everything a child needs to start on the writing journey. The erasable pages are very sturdy and save paper. Being able to instantly erase a mistake also allows children to feel they have as many chances as they need to create beautiful letters. I could also see this book being used by teachers in a classroom setting.

~The Rebecca Review

title: What a perfect invention and life saver to have..!!!! text: This was a hit for my teenage son who loves to build mini skateboards/fingerboards.. Problem we were having, the small nuts, bolts, screws are so tiny and if dropped… They go MIA. Especially, if working over carpet or- at a higher counter level! These tiny pieces of hardware love to bounce and hide-
Tbh, I didn’t know this item existed and thought I had revolutionized the world with my million $ making idea- plan was to Patton a magnetized placemat… and retire! However, when I popped that brilliance into Google a “how to” search engine- I was kicked in the gut to find, I could already buy this item of mine on Amazon! Of course, I could! At least I felt smart for a tiny hot second.. thinking it up on my own- and along with the someone else who, was a step ahead and had earned my money maker.. dammit! Next time, definitely next time...
As for the product, it works just as one would expect. It is simply just that, a placemat to do ones task on and one with impressive powers- this has a good amount of grab to keep items from falling off if dropped or set down on top of it. And it’s easy to remove… It’s a nice amount of give/take.
If small eyeglass type/size screw is placed on the mat- you could pick it up horizontally without items falling off. On the flipside, one rough shake will release (not that you’re wanting to do that! Just giving the idea of the holding power!!) trust me, the small items and wheel bearings my son is working with, would make the back of an earring look massive.. so, this mat has saved many of hours on hands/knees combing floor with a magnet- so, for any who work with tiny object such as this.. it’s worth it’s weight in gold!
This also comes with a magnetic pen to pick up small items as well… he uses that more like a novelty item. This would be helpful for those who have trouble seeing some of the smaller parts.
This also has a grid system for any specific parts needing to be placed together.. in specific boxes marked on the magnet board, you can arrange your items keeping them compartmentalized… Amazing!
This comes in a slide in/out plastic cover and if you open appropriately… You can use cover to store item when not in use- we did this and love that it’s easy to keep together or take on the go.
For any who work with smaller objects at just over $5, this is a great item to have.. Definitely satisfied and glad I thought of it and purchased it!!

title: Perfect for the new school year text: With the new school year that started up after summer ended, the scramble for school supplies was on. While the stores have the basic supplies such as binders and loose leaf, the missing piece for my son was the daily planner to keep track of his assignments.

This planner for the 2021-2022 school year fit the bill nicely. It has a durable cover and the design is light-hearted.

It is not a compact spiral notebook as many planners but this larger size has its advantages as well. The boxes are larger and more text can be written.

title: Gadgety, but NOT Practical text: I hate these.

First, the stickiness of the 'regular' Post-its are much stronger. With the originals, I can stick and re-stick several times to our bathroom mirror (helpful for weekly reminders and the like), as well as to my office door ("I'm in 248 today"). With these, they fail after one or two moves. Even when just sticking them to a single surface, you will find that they are easier to pull/fall off. I have tested them side-by-side, and the 'normal' notes consistently outperform these. You can see this yourself if you stick a normal pad of Post-it notes into the pop-up dispenser. You can pick up the dispenser with the stickiness of the normal notes, whereas the pop-ups come out 'cleanly'. Or just put them on a table side-by-side, like I did, and see which one comes up more easily.

Second, these are more expensive than regular Post-its. How so, you ask? Well, they are incredibly frustrating to use without a dispenser, so you really shouldn't buy them unless you also buy one of those. That will set you back another $5-10 on top of the notes (although it is reusable).

Finally, to use these with the dispenser, you HAVE to write on them AFTER you pull them off the pad. If you are posting them to a wall or other vertical surface, this generally means sticking them to a table or some such, writing, then moving them elsewhere. Since they are already weaker (see #1), this greatly increases the chances of them falling off by accident.

In short, these are 'neat' and 'gadgety', but not actually practical. Use these as a fun little party trick. Stick to the plain old "boring" Post-its when you actually need to make sure your message gets across.

title: PROS/CONS - UPDATE! text: UPDATE: OK it's been almost SIX months since I stuck these to two concrete bumpers (my parking spaces) in front of my apt. I thought I would have to use additional adhesive eventually, BUT haven't had to and it's been REALLY HOT this summer, and we've been well below freezing and they're still SECURELY ON! With just the adhesive that is on them, so GREAT DEAL. PLUS they look very professional and high end.
__________________________________________________

EDIT: I had to put them up FAST as people were parking in my spaces. I just used the adhesive that came with it, thinking I would pull them off and use the super glue later. Well, it's been weeks now. Weeks with rain, humidity, heat and they're still sticking to the cement block! I have my super glue on hand should they loosen, but so far, so VERY good!
_______________________

I bought two, one for each of two parking space cement bumpers in front of my apt. I KNOW it doesn't say to use for that, although it does say INDOOR/OUTDOOR (which likely means just an outside door or wall, but still it does say OUTDOOR).

WILL UPDATE my comments after some time has gone by.

PROS:

QUALITY/PRESENTATION: THESE look exceptionally good! Not cheap, they look like something you would see in a professional building. Silver gray letters on a black background. We shall see if the elements fade it and how long it takes but the letters look like they're UNDER a coat of clear plastic.
Makes my parking spaces look really official now!

COST: HARD to beat getting two of these for about $10 total.

SIZE: PERFECT for the middle of the cement bumper which is only about 4 inches high.

CONS:
While not necessarily a con yet, let's talk adhesive.
What you get is two SMALL double sided adhesive rectangles per sign.
I would be surprised if that stayed well on an outside door, but hard to tell how strong the adhesive is.
I FIGURED no matter what adhesive (and I kind of expected a long strip across the length of sign, where you just rip off the cover over it and attach), not likely to stick long to a cement bumper that is exposed to the elements,
SO I got some super glue with a brush (really inexpensive, I think it was about three bucks here on Amazon and I don't need a ton). HOPEFULLY this will hold in HOT or COLD temps (it says it will, we shall see).

title: Mixed bag text: I liked this chair when I first got it, but there is one massive issue that is causing me to re-evaluate my opinion. The lumbar support is too aggressive, not very customizable (only up/down, not back/forth aggressiveness), and impossible to remove without damaging the chair (which I did anyway).

I have back issues from a previous injury and have been having much more pain in the past year. I finally realized that this pain was correlated to days spent sitting in this chair specifically. I wasn't a fan of the lumbar support already but decided to remove it. Unfortunately the Phillips head screws that secure the lumbar support to the back of the chair air pointed toward the netting, making them difficult to access without special tooling (a ratchet screwdriver for instance).

The seat is also incredibly squeaky after a year of mixed use. My Zoom chats will highlight my video because my mic picks it up.

Otherwise it's a great height, decent padding, and decent quality.

title: Great size, easy to use ... text: I use these labels to let buyers know what's "inside the card" on my hand-crafted greeting cards.

I put each card and envelope in a sealed clear plastic envelope, and put one of these stickers on the back of the plastic envelope. I use the Avery website to design and print the labels on my MacBook Pro, and I've never had a problem with them. I set up the basic design ("Inside the card:"), and type each card's inside text or verse below that. Works great every time.

The labels themselves are great quality, easy to remove from the backing, and adhere well to the plastic. No need to look further; these are perfect for my needs.

It does use FIVE AAA batteries, which seems like a lot.  Batteries don't come with it.  The only problem I have encountered with this phone is that it does not work with an inline call blocking device that I have.  I have a mechanical call blocker that goes between the phone line and the phone, but if that device is plugged in, the phone will not work.  It doesn't even have to be plugged into this phone; put it anywhere on the line and it makes this phone go dead.  Unfortunately the phone itself doesn't include a call blocking feature, which is too bad.  Being sold as a business phone, it should have call blocking.

text: I should have bought quality first. Over the years, I have bought several wimpy, low capacity shredders. This surpasses them all and I can see myself having this shredder for a decade to come.  I bought the manufacturer’s oil to take care of my investment.  If you follow the directions, it will perform well.  This also helped me in my decluttering project.  I shredded two totes of old financial papers over a couple of days and it performed beautifully. I prefer to do my own shredding rather than drop it off where it sits around for days.  Also, if shredding services cost $10 per pound, buying this is worth the Investment.  I can roll it from room to room, but it is not something that can be taken up and down stairs easily.

title: Can't Go Wrong w/These Stickers!
text: This is my second roll of Hemerka's 'FRAGILE HANDLE WITH CARE' stickers.  The first roll worked so well, I immediately ordered a second roll when my supply dwindled.  I use these stickers on almost a daily basis for bottles of nail polish I sell online.  They stick to the bubble mailers I use beautifully. Once a sticker is on the mailer, that's where it stays.  They don't lift up, unpeel or tear.  A few have been outside in light rain while waiting to be picked up by the post office and they STILL stayed on the mailer envelope. They're easy to remove from the roll as well and the bright red color of the sticker alerts everyone that the package is to be handled carefully. I've yet to receive one complaint of a polish bottle breaking. They're an excellent size and the price can't be beat, especially when we're talking about 1,000 labels per roll.  No doubt about it,  I will continue to use and purchase Hemerka's 'FRAGILE HANDLE WITH CARE' stickers.  HIGHLY recommended!

text: I was expecting a lot, after much research, review reading and spending oh so much more than I had intended. But SAIJI has exceeded my expectations! I'm totally impressed by how well it's made and how easy it is to change configurations: height, tilt etc.  I'm 71 years young and when I'm home I like to get my feet elevated with as much as possible within reach. I bought this one because of all the extras like the book stand which even holds by big bible. Storage drawer for glasses, pens, highlighters. So much more substantial  than I expected. i-phone very secure. Everything can be moved  to left or right or middle. I can even use this while in my recliner to my surprise. The design of the ski-runner legs is brilliant because the pulling in and pushing out of a legged tray weighted with laptop, books, phone etc.on fabrics can be tricky. No problem now, wether on the bed duvet or on the recliner, it just slides and everything remains where I had put it. Very light weight, when not in use I just slide it under my bed.

title: Perfect laptop table to work from the convenience of your bed text: This is a very nice laptop stand that works very well. It is very well built and very sturdy. On the top of it is an insert in which you can place your phone or the book stand that is secured for storage on the underside of the stand. On the bottom end of it is a little ledge that prevents your laptop and your mouse from sliding off. In addition there is a little grove in which you can put some pens or the little laptop stopper if you think the ledge is not enough.

On the left side is a little drawer in which you can keep your mouse, USB cables, pens, laptop stopper and other small items in. The legs can be raised up so you can adjust it to what you prefer. They are wide enough apart to give you plenty of space. In addition the angle of the top can be changed as well so you can adjust to to your preference. When you are done everything can be folded neatly to one flat surface that be easily stored away.

This is a very nicely put together laptop table. It is very sturdy and easy to use I also like that you can use this to eat when you are in bed, especially post a surgery for example when you are bed ridden for a bit and it is not as easy for you to get around and need some pampering.

title: Red button is more depressed than all others, none sticks text: I will rate the Canon P1-DHV-3 a weak 4 star rating, 4 for the actual calculator and a -1 due to the terrible manual. I accessed the PDF version of the single folded oversized page online at the Canon website that is printed on the box and printed a copy which looks to be a reduced version of exactly the same paper, so now I have one clean and unfolded pair of papers in addition to the folded and wrinkly large sheet.

As for the actual printing calculator, it is better then the last one I purchased, a Casio that is about 20+ years old and still functional, in that it is clean and new and close to the same size. It uses the same size rolls of paper, some things never change, but be aware that this one comes out of the box with one of the small test rolls. If you intend to print on paper, stock up because the included roll is about an inch diameter and that includes a thick cardboard core which leaves you with about 1/2 inch maximum thickness on the roll. The ink roller is a replaceable CP-16, good to know if you print a lot. Included in the box is a set of 4 AA batteries but there is no AC adapter in the box, so you'll have to purchase that separately. It plugs into the rear of the unit, behind the paper holder wire. I do not care for the wire due to its small gauge and lack of any holding contraption to keep the roll in the calculator and not unwound on the floor behind the desk if it's been knocked over. This is a pet peeve of many printing calculators for me because I've experienced the flying paper roll too many times. It seldom occurs with full rolls, but these little ones seem to grow wings as the paper is depleted and the roll becomes lighter.

Functionally, this calculator does what is described, having the currency conversion and cost-sell-margin functions escalate it to the level above basics. Because the paper roll flows so freely, I would not call it a "Handheld" printing calculator as it's described on the box, but with a little creativity, I will be fabricating something to keep the roll in place so that I can use it in the hand and not on the desk to try it out. It is described as "Desktop" on Amazon and that's what I'd call it.

title: Nice for Small Measuring Needs text: This is an attractive, good looking scale. My husband and I find that some of our favorite recipes require weight measurements instead of standard measuring cups and spoons. It gives a more accurate measurement that way. This scale works very well for small measurements. We found that for some larger cooking measurements, this scale's range wasn't large enough. My husband will often put the large mixing bowl on the scale and set it to zero, then add an ingredient. Then he'll reset it to zero and add the next one. He does this to save on dish washing afterwards. This scale only measures up to 17 ounces and most of our mixing bowls weigh more than that empty. With that being said, this is working out very well for measuring the chemicals for the hot tub. It also works well for measuring mail to calculate postage. This scale is easy to use and works well. It came with batteries, so it was ready to use almost immediately.

*I purchased this at a discounted price in exchange for my honest & unbiased review. My thoughts & opinions are my own.

title: Useful and sturdy text: This is a review for the black, ladder back chair with a vinyl padded seat, not the wooden seat.

Just wanted to make clear which chair I am reviewing.

Okay, here goes, this chair is okay and almost perfect.

Here's what I like about it;

1.Very sturdy design and a bit heavier than I was expecting. My last chair was wood, it had cross beams near the bottom and I liked to rest my feet on them. So would anyone under seven feet tall, which made it so disappointing when the cross beam broke and compromised the chair leg (there was a smallish crack in it and the chair seemed wobbly). With metal frame and overall great construction of this chair, I can rest my legs with peace of mind, no broken chairs for me!!!

2. Looks exactly like the photo. All black and the exact dimensions that were listed here.

Here's what I didn't like;

1. Missing hardware. there was spots for six screws to secure the seat to the base and yet only two screws were included. Sure, it seemed sturdy, but why not have all six points locked down?

2. this is not a seat for lounging. In fact, the butt space is a on the small side, even my skinny teen found the seat to be a bit wee. I will still use it and be glad to have it, but it feels a bit like you will slide right off if you don't sit up straights.

For the price, this is a pretty good chair.

title: The Best I've Ever Used text: Purchased these after a lifetime of using cheap pencils. The difference between these and regular colored pencils like Crayola is that these are soft and will permit you to blend and layer colors similar in the way that oil paints do. They lay down smoothly and with varying degrees of pressure will not streak or show bare spots of uncolored paper. Mine arrived sharpened in the tin and I haven't experienced any core breakage. They are a bit expensive as compared with lower quality pencils, but you have to remember that these are premier premium quality. The old adage "you get what you pay for" in this case certainly rings true. Are there any better? Maybe, possibly, probably but I am well satisfied with their performance.

Bottom line: Excellent pencils for those looking to improve their art or just simply to play around with.

title: Great Portability, Not Overly Strong text: I like this tripod for what it is. It is a very portable sign holder that can easily hold a foam core sign or other, extremely light signage or art. But there are some trade offs made by choosing light weight portability.

For one this is not a heavy use product. I would not expect the tent pole bungy technology to survive a lot of abuse, However it is very handy and mades for easy set up and it breaks down to a very nice, packable size.Also the tripod is a little tippy and easily knocked over due to the lack of cross supports which were probably left out for portability.

I wouldn't push this tripod with anything weighty. I have not had problems with the adjustable brackets, but again I am not using anything other than foam core signage. I would think that weight would risk slippage of the brackets and possible twisting of the legs.

Pros
+ easily packed
+ Easy set up.

Cons
- Light weight
- Tippy
- Low holding strength.

Summary.
This really is a nice solution if you are looking for an easy to pack light weight sign holder. If you have more demanding requirements I would go up a step, but at the expense of losing and quick set up and lightweight, tight packing.

title: Good multifunctional color laser machine with minimal weaknesses text: With close to a month of usage, the Samsung SL-C1860FW/XAA Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax is providing a much appreciated upgrade to my home office. Its larger than I'd expected, but I had not researched its size prior to requesting the machine. The box I received was intact and it required two of us to remove the product from the package. Setting it up was problematic at first because there was no CD to be found anywhere. After I'd downloaded the manual from the Samsung website, I finally found the CD hidden inside the box, so if you purchase this and can't find the CD, keep looking. Enclosed in clear sight was a warranty and two folded pages with installation information. I found them to be convoluted, but that could be my problem. I also had difficulty connecting this to my network, and finally was able to connect wirelessly. I honestly do not know the steps I took, but it does work and it's securely a part of my own network. The cartridges are easy and quick to install, as is the paper tray. I was apprehensive with the tray because it was more lightweight than those on the enormous laser printers I used in days past. Visually, this machine is attractive and boxy, neutral in colors and the screen is very intuitive and clear. Although not required per the documentation, I downloaded the Samsung software on our smartphones and we are not using this printer in this manner rather than using Google Cloud. I've not attempted to use the NFC Print via the one smartphone with capabilities only because I haven't needed that yet.

Copying is fast and accurate, crisp and clean. Scans are fantastic and reliable. The fax I tested was successful. Printing was equally successful when sent via USB or WiFi. The option to print configurations is appreciated, as that allows for keeping all information in a folder kept near the printer. I use the Eco mode because I don't use the machine every day. I haven't notice warmth around the machine and it is quiet when not functional. For my home office, the speed of printing is great, and although I likely will not use this for as much dedicated color printing as my other inkjet printers, for documents which include color, this is better than my other printers. The major weakness for my needs is that this does not have duplex printing. I have yet to experience a paper jam. I'm far from needing replacement toners, but hope that their prices are reduced before that day comes. My initial thought regarding the cost of this machine was that it's priced higher than it is worth, but considering the cost of the stuff that goes onto the paper is about the same as this entire package, I guess I won't complain. If you are in the market for a very good color multifunctional printer, this is definitely worth considering.

title: Amazing feature set and good quality results text: Bought this on Newegg on special for $160 with free shipping. Ordered on Sunday night and had it on Tuesday. I usually love Amazon but in this case Newegg was much better. In sum, you really can't find a better combination of features and quality for the price. The only real complaint I have is that sometimes documents fed through the automatic document feeder aren't 100 percent straight (more like 98 percent straight, but this is only a problem sometimes).

PROS: Auto-duplexing for input and output; 35-page document feeder; great quality when using high print settings; good speed at all settings (unless it's 2-sided); two paper inputs allows you to keep two different papers in the printer at all times, or to just close the top feed if you want; fast and high quality faxing with lots of features (fax isn't just an afterthought in this machine); multiple ink tanks means no disposing of partially full ink cartridges; very good driver software gives you lots of printing options through your computer; many copy, fax and scan options built into the machine and accessible through nice rotating LCD screen; no paper jams yet (UPDATED: Still no jams after over three months of continuous use!).

CONS: It's BIG, as in seriously big and heavy too; like I said above, about one-third of the time documents fed through the document feeder are just the slightest bit off; duplex printing is slow because it stops for ten seconds to let the ink dry on one side before printing the other side; text printed at low quality can be fuzzy, definitely use high print quality for important documents; it's a little on the noisy side and even has a "quiet mode" that I haven't tried yet; after two weeks of use I had to run the "unclog nozzle" routine to make some black streaking go away (I realize that maintenance is needed sometimes but after just two weeks seems a bit soon); would be nice if it came with a USB cable; photo printing gobbles up ink.

Overall so far I'm quite satisfied, though if the document feeder issue gets worse before the one year warranty expires I'll send it to Canon for service. And if need be I can always place documents on the glass by hand. Without that issue I'd give it 5 stars.

(Note, after 13 months of use this printer fell off a table and stopped working. So be careful and don't drop your printer.)

title: Truly Outstanding High-Security Shredder With One Problem text: This is an extraordinarily high quality micro-cut shredder for the price. The main shredding unit has functioned perfectly - hasn’t stopped to cool down in all my usage (about two basketfulls of output so far). Outside the US market this product might cost the equivalent of $80-100 usd and would highly recommend.

Shredding is a good practice because it maintains security while reducing waist (one small basket of micro cut pieces could be the equivalent of dozens of pieces of junk mail).

Only issue - the crack. It seems the basket build quality is not on par with the shredding unit. A large crack (pictured) has emerged, and its large enough for paper bits to fall out. Not sure how long it will manage to support the main shredding unit.

Quite possible my experience with the crack is a one-off, so will not subtract any stars; plus the price was excellent (about $36 iirc). Highly recommended.

title: Very nice desk! Well made and very sturdy text: Very nice desk! Well made and very sturdy. Only two things I wish were different: 1) the keyboard tray is a little small - just enough room for a keyboard and mouse but not a lot of space to navigate the mouse. It's still a great desk it would just be nice to have a little more room. 2) there is a raised edge around the keyboard tray. Not a problem when standing but when used in the sitting position it rubs on my wrists. Not rough or sharp - just a little annoying pressure. To avoid this I usually pull my keyboard and mouse off when sitting and put it on my regular desk.

Overall this is a great desk. I love the infinite locking system and how sturdy it is. I have two monitors and it is very stable regardless of how high it is set. Also I was pleasantly surprised with how big the upper platform is. Plenty of room for both monitors plus mug, planner, etc. which is very helpful when in the standing position. title: Great until it prints a page in color. text: I have an all-in-one brother laser printer that is black and white and I love it, so when my 10 year old HP color laser printer gave up the ghost, I thought I would try this one. Overall... it wasn't the best purchase.

PROS
1- Extremely easy setup. I set it up to work off of my network print server, as well as wirelessly within about 5 minutes. I was then able to install and setup 2 Mac computers and 3 PC computers within 20 minutes. All worked fine and printed without issue to the printer.
2- Relatively quiet compared to my old HP.
3- Print speed
4- Price

CONS
1- Really, the only problem I found with it was the print quality when printing in color. I was so disappointed. Like I said, I switched from a 10 year-old HP color laser. The colors on my HP were vibrant and true to what my photographs showed. The colors on this printer's (Brother MFC-9840CDW) print-out were horribly washed out and almost made it look like the photographs were actually faded.

Although the price of the printer was excellent, I am going to return mine because of the color print quality. If you don't care about that, this printer is great in every other way. However, if you are looking for vibrant, true colors, like your photographs show... then I would go with a different printer.

title: Maybe I received a bum unit? text: After waiting for the delivery of this talking travel translator, I now have to wait for it to actually translate. It arrived intact in a little package without much non-recyclable materials, just the disposable plastic case which is easy to open and not much larger than the actual 3/4 of a deck of cards size of the translator. Included was a sheet of paper with 705 English travel related phrases, and a second sheet of paper which is the schematics and operating manual. Both are in English, folded and double-sided. Now for a review of the product.

PROS:
A voice announces what is on a little screen and you can change the language through any or all 7 options.
With one button, you can hear it in your "Home" language.
Favorites can be saved.
It is small and lightweight.
If you study this, you can learn phrases and speak them yourself, maybe after showing the display to a person who speaks the language you want to learn.
You can enter addresses.

CONS:
If it needs to be reset or batteries fail, you lose all your addresses and saved favorites and there is no way to backup.
It is not very sturdy in the hand and the buttons often have to be depressed more than once.
Buttons are small, but the letters on the word imprints are as tiny as a tick before dinner.
Arrow buttons don't always work and sometimes simply turn off the device.
Digital display scrolls slowly with push of button alone to display the phrase.
Backlight button is exactly the reverse of the manual's description and it turns off and on with no apparent logic.
Audio quality is lousy with some phrases being unintelligible, even in my native English.
Spanish has an extra audio blip on almost all phrase endings.
Volume button on the rear feels like it doesn't click into the three levels but slides too freely.
Volume often becomes weird with a sound that lasts for minutes of translations.
You cannot see a phrase number, then enter the number. You need to scroll through each level and then you can save that phrase as favorite, then scroll through your favorites to access it again.

Observations:
There are so many phrases with negative connotations that it makes me want to stay at home with the doors locked. Examples include: 661 There is no electricity. 671 There are cockroaches in my room. 672 There is a smell of gas. 139 I have been bitten by a dog. 150 I have been attacked. 151 I have been raped. 162 I would like to speak to a woman. (There is no "I would like to speak to a man.") 171 Someone has stolen my..... (You can add another word like -- 474 Eggs, 463 Rib, 484 Pancake, 378 Whisky, 282 Two kilos of....)

This translator was a disappointment to me because I expected the "Over 4900 Travel Related Phrases" to be phrases and not single words like days of the week, months, numbers, seasons and foods. On the other hand, sports include soccer, tennis, table tennis, golf, baseball, badmitton, and nothing more. I will continue to explore the gadget in the hopes of finding it more useful, but the main impression it made on me is that in order to use this effectively, one must follow the suggestion of phrase number 705, "Slowly, please."

I keep a variety of different engraved stationary, pre-printed cards and generic note cards with envelopes on hand at all times.

This set is pretty basic, but does meet the requirements for a quick get well notes. The color selection is bright and cheerful with every hue you could want. The cards are thin, but not flimsy. The envelopes are pretty thin too and I don't really trust the seams, so I'm taping them closed before putting them in the mail. For basic, simple cards, this is a good box with a bunch in it - I could see using these for casual party invitations too.

title: Works perfectly with The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game. text: I didn't get these for regular playing cards, but they work fine for that. What I wanted to use these for are my solo LotR: LCG games. That game requires a lot of table space and, while I consolidated some space using dice, there's still a lot of space to save.

Once the package arrived, I was surprised--though pleasantly so--to find how heavy the box was. The two stands come packaged in a box, which I keep to put these away in. The stands are solid. I have no concerns of their longevity. There are nice felt bottoms, but they stay in place when I need them. Each slot can fit two double-sleeved cards together, but no more. That's fine, since most of my setup doesn't require more than that. The slots are spaced far apart to allow only the very tops of the cards to be seen when behind another. That's fine for playing cards, but I wish they were spaced just a bit more. C'est la vie.

title: If I Could Give This More Than 5 Stars I Would! text: This book stand is perfect!! The cushion is soft enough to be comfortable when propped on my lap/leg, but sturdy enough to stay at the angle I choose. The book clips work great; I read a 400+ page hardback book with the clips attached to the covers and the pages free. Left my hands free to grab my lemonade and to pet my dogs! I recently had foot surgery, so I’m using a “knee wheelie” to get around. When I need to move this book stand’s handle fits over my handlebars and it goes with me. I attach the clips to hold down the pages in my book and take off; holds a heavy hardcover book in place while I zoom around, without losing my place in the book! Added bonuses: the clips have rubber tips to keep them from tearing the cover/pages, and a bookmark holder in the left upper corner.
*I just purchased another one for my husband, who loves to read (almost!) as much as I do.*

title: Gorgeous set. I am in love with the glass pen! text: This Glass Dip Pen Set is gorgeous. I am in love with the glass pen. The feather pen is a close second. I was excited to see this set when it arrived. I opened it immediately and started using the glass pen first and then the feather pen. I am learning calligraphy and the feather pen works great for that.

The set comes with a glass pen with a holder, a feather pen with a holder, 5 nibs, and 10 beautiful colors of ink. The ink comes with a stopper so the ink will not leak out. This set would make a great gift for almost anybody.

I will be recommending this Glass Dip Pen Set to family and friends.

title: Upgraded Staple Gun
text: As a female DIYer I have fought with staple guns of all manner over the many years. This one is quite an improvement in the ease of which I can be loaded. The staple compartment is accessible and easier to load. Instead of pushing the staples along the feeder mechanism, you turn this one upside down and load them from the bottom. The tension can be controlled by the plus or minus lever and all the staples I shot into a pine board were flush. No need to go behind and pound them in. Even with my age and limited hand strength I was able to squeeze the handle to use this. I gave 4 stars originally, but took one off for quality. By the time I had loaded the staples the rubber side inserts were already lose and falling off. They actually are not even pictured here in what I am seeing. Since they are not a functional part of the gun, I think this will still be fine.

title: I bought these last February as a present for myself text: I had a rag tag set of Prismacolor pencils that I had been accumulating for over 30 years one at a time. I handed them over to my daughter in law and bought a set of new pencils for myself. I never felt more powerful than the day these arrived. Thank you for pre-sharpening them. I jumped in and made a color chart right away. If you don't do this, you're missing out on a chance to see what they can do before actually committing to a project. Since then I've charted all of my pencils, paints, and pastels. Very satisfying and a great reference tool when I'm looking for the "right" color to work with.

The wax based pencils are fabulous. Acquaint yourself with things like wax bloom and fixatives. Minor annoyances but well worth the small amount of time you put in to counter the issues.

I recommend the following books if you're a newbie: The Colored Pencil Solution Book by Janie Gildow and Alonya Nickelsen's Colored Pencil Painting Bible. And anything by Gary Greene, but be prepared to whine about not getting as much for your money. Buy it anyway. You'll be glad you did. Eventually.

title: Great White For Resin Special Effects text: When it comes to resin, one of the colors of alcohol ink that I blow through quickly is white. I needed another source for it. This was perfect.

HOW THIS COMES
This comes in a squeeze bottle with a brush you can fill the compartment with alcohol to spread the ink. I have not used it with ink as I am not sure if it would plug up the brush.

HOW THIS WORKS
I use this to mix micas or other colors of alcohol inks with and drizzle them through the resin for great serendipitous designs. It works great for that. The white drags the other colors of mica down into the resin as it sets and it looks beautiful 3D.

WHAT ELSE?
I have not used this for alcohol ink paintings, although I can and probably will. I prefer to use it with resin most of the time. I also do use this for highlights on my watercolor or other media paintings when I need that tiny accent that I want to stay put.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This ink is a great resource to have. I use it all of the time in resin, but also appreciate having it for highlights, or paintings in the future.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. This is great. I like the larger bottle. It makes it easier than to have so many little bottles of it around.

title: Sturdier Than Many Other Carts I Have Built text: They call me the cart queen. That's right. The cart queen. Why, you might ask? It is because in order to deal with the fall out from a flood inspired remodel, I have found that using carts with many shelves is superior to stacking endless boxes everywhere. I can move them quickly and store just as much or more in the floor space without straining my back. I have a LOT of other carts to compare this one to.

HOW THIS COMES
This comes in a box, well wrapped in plastic and cushioned from damage. All of the parts are in great bags and the instructions are clear.

DOES IT COME WITH TOOLS?
This does come with tools, but the Allen Key is a bit flimsy, so you might want to bring out your own if you have them and get better results. It strips easily.

ASSEMBLY
The assembly of this cart is not difficult. It took a bit of pressure to get a few holes lined up, but that was not a big issue. The shelves are descending in size so you have to be sure to use them in order. They are clearly marked with numbers again- excellent feature.

STURDY
This is one of the more sturdy carts I have built. The shelves are metal and the design is not wobbly like so many of them are when you load them up with semi substantial items.

WHEELS
The wheels of this cart are again smoother and better made than many of the other carts I have used. they are metal and rubberized material so they are not cheap plastic.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This is a really nice cart. The space between shelves make it easy to store just about anything I need to store. The sturdy way that this holds items is much better than others.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I like this cart a lot. It took me a while to build it because I had to clear a spot for it, but I am glad I did. I saved one of the best for last. This one is a winner for me so far.

title: WOW!!! text: A couple of years ago, I looked at my checking account balance and found most of my money gone. I went online and saw that it was taken by "Government of" a country that never existed. Though I was reimbursed by my bank, it took weeks to get the money back. Not fun when you are an old fart like me, on a fixed income and then sweat just to get your cat his food.
I bought one of those security ink stampers but noticed that even after multiple stamping, you could still make out important information, especially if you held a letter at an angle to a strong light. It was most notable on correspondence printed with a laser printer.
Granted, I've only had this shredder for a few days. So far, it's fantastic. Turns my paper into confetti. I should have gotten this years ago.

UPDATE : It's amazing how many things that you receive have your name, address and a bar code with only god knows what info is in that it you get. It really is a treasure trove for a thief. Preapproved offers of credit, I have learned, are a gold mine for the bad guys. Even a receipt from a store, if you paid with anything other than cash, will have a ton of info on it. Shred the damn paper.

title: Definitely some pros and cons text: This envelope making board has its pros and cons. I had purchased the original gray design with white lettering about 4 years ago. Although the print is small, I could read it without any issue at all. Then when I spotted the new pretty blue and white punch board I thought why not. I
use my old one so much that I thought it would be nice to have a much prettier one, ong with a new punch blade to justify my senseless purchase. Big mistake! The pretty new design is extremely difficult to read the tiny print. The background color is blue with white font. I never struggle to read anything, but I do with this.
My suggestion is that if you are also having an issue reading yours, just print the measurements out on a piece of paper to store away with the board.
The other issue I have is that when making the larger envelopes, the board itself is not large enough to accommodate your paper. And I mean for envelopes only like 4x6 or larger. The paper hangs off the board so you can’t score the entire paper. I have made 100+ envelopes of all sizes so it can be done regardless, but sometimes my score lines are off a bit because of this and I end up with a crooked envelope that can’t be fixed. So I end up having to throw the wonky envelope one in my scrap pile for another project.
PROS: Despite all mentioned above, I still find this method far easier that cutting everything by hand, which I did for years before the board.
Initially I thought there was something wrong with the design because all my envelopes came out wrong. I watched a YouTube video and got the hang of it after making 3-4 envelopes and now it’s a breeze and the process is very fast.
My 3 star review is because the new color combination is hard to read for some. And another star dinged because this really needs to be on a larger board platform. Us crafters spend our $ like crazy on our hobby, so why not make a larger version for $10 more. I sure would buy it! Don’t take the reviews seriously that say it
doesn’t work. They just don’t have patience and the willingness to learn something new. Quitters never win :)

title: Slippery, Clunky to adjust, Way too tall for a lap desk text: I am 5'7" tall. This is not made for humans my size (or shorter) for use as a lap desk.

The photos show items sitting on the desk on full tilt, such as the phone and the ipad, staying in place. They had to glue those down, or those are photoshopped images, because this is so slippery, that even on the lowest tilt my mouse and laptop fly all over the place. Using a wireless magic mouse, so my mouse on the screen goes all over. This is also way way too tall to use as a lapdesk - unless you like carpel tunnel and shoulder/arm pain, it's the complete opposite of ergonomic. I didn't expect it would be, but I also didn't expect it to be so bad. I thought because of those photos, it would be possible to actually sit on the couch. I have deep seating, so figured it would be fine - it's not. Even with deep seats, the tips of the legs don't sit on the couch at all - about 4 inches stick out - and it's so high up, tilt doesn't help. You do NOT want to keep your arms up so high when working, and with this on the lowest height, my arms were raised up very high, maybe 11 inches higher than they should be for proper posture. Use at your own risk!!

I think this would be useful for kids to color or have a snack while sitting on the floor - this is NOT for professionals using it to work on, and I wouldn't even be able to use this for a few minutes on a laptop for any reason. It's not comfortable, it's not possible to keep your laptop and mouse from sliding all over the desk unless it's completely flat with no tilt - which is impossible to use.

title: Poorly Engineered
text: I cannot believe that I have to sacrifice almost an inch of tape on each label if I want my text centered on a PT-210 label.  Sometime that makes the labels too long.  I have an older, less expensive PT-80 that allows me to have nice, short margins.  I have seen some of the work-arounds, but none of them should be necessary.  If I want smaller margins on at least one side, I need to also have a pair of scissors handy and a broom for all those little extra pieces cut from the left of the two dots [the manual cut line for a centered label].  Worse, with all the good reviews, I expected to love the PT-210 and bought a two pack of tape.  I wasted all the sample tape just trying to get my labels to come out centered, with smaller side margins, and not needing to use scissors.  I guess this PT-210 and labels go on Craigslist.  My next label maker certainly will not be a Brother, nor will any other product.  Crappy engineering on one item [Brother confirmed that there is no "fix" for this] isn't a particularly good advertisement for future purchases.

title: Run out of ink too quickly text: I bought a three pack of these pens to use for grading essays. When I started on the most recent batch — 64 students, and most essays were two pages, hand written — I had a pen that was partially used. It ran out before I was halfway through, so I took out a new one. That one just ran out, and I still have five essays to go.

While I like the feel of this pen in my hand, and I like the smoothness with which it moves across the paper, I cannot recommend it because of the startling speed with which it runs out of ink. I have never had a single pen not make it through one stack of essays, much less not be able to do it with one full pen and another partial one. And there have been years when I had closer to 90 students in the course.

title: Outstanding printer, great value text: I had a Canon BubbleJet BJC-4200 long ago, and after that printer I was very hesitant to even consider another Canon printer. When my most recent printer died, an HP DeskJet 970cse, I needed to find a good printer that could print duplex and produce quality output. After reading many, many reviews I decided to give Canon another chance. I am very glad that I did so.

The Pixma iP4500 arrived in a huge box, and as it turns out it needed the space. This is a larger printer than I expected, and as a result I had to rearrange my desk to find room for it. That's a small oversight on my part. The printer itself is an unassuming-looking box of a machine, though it resembles more of a printer when the paper trays are populated.

Setup was easy and straightforward, though I do recommend using the "getting started" insert before setting everything up. Though setting everything up is relatively self-explanatory, it is helpful to see the illustration of what to do in order before making the leap. Overall, setup took maybe 20-30 minutes once the parts were all out of the box and everything was set up.

Once configured, installing the drivers is simple. Drop in the CD, follow the prompts, and turn on the printer at the right time. No fuss.

Once set up and powered on, the printer is ready to go to work. I print a majority of my things in duplex mode so I tweaked the driver configuration to make it the default, after which the setting is more or less invisible. Everything in the driver configuration is very easy to find, straightforward, and simple.

There are two ways to feed paper into the iP4500. There is a top-loader which is the default paper source and there is a front-loading paper tray ("cassette" according to Canon's documentation). Heavier papers such as card stock should be loaded from the top-loader.

So, how does this printer perform? I'll break it down into two parts, speed and quality.

Speed - this is a relatively fast printer! Feeding it a print job that conists of a two-sided black and white print this printer can churn out the pages, including the dry time for the front page, in about 20 seconds. Granted, this is my experience and your mileage may vary but it's a good starting point from which to base your evaluation of the speed. My previous printer would take at least a minute to print the very same documents, and it still couldn't keep up when in draft mode. For photo printing it churns out a full-page 8.5"x11" borderless photo in roughly 45 seconds.

Quality - what good is speed without quality? This printer backs it up. The text and basic image quality is acceptable, though it could be a touch better. This is not noticeable in day-to-day print jobs. On photo printing, though, this printer is an absolute showstopper. The photos it prints, on photo paper, are better than most magazine prints and could easily be used for photo studio gallery shots.

It would be nice if the printer actually had a USB cable in the box, but this is a small thing.

Overall, this is a high-quiality, high-performance printer that is sure to please even the staunchest of critics. It is fast, creates beautiful output, and is very easy to set up.

title: Does everything I need; very heavy, but not a large footprint; fast; quiet
text: I am giving this 5-stars with some reservations.  First of, the cons.  The printer is very heavy and I had a hard time getting it out of the box; almost pulled a muscle.  Also had a hard time lifting it up on the table where it will sit.  I am 70 and I can just barely handle 40 pounds of weight; this weighs in at approximately 50 pounds.  If you can't handle 50 pounds and don't have help to lift and place it, don't get this printer.  The other concern I have is how long the toner cartridges might last and I have seen some say they have had problems with the printer reporting toner out before it is, but apparently there are ways to get full use of the cartridges before they are truly out, so it may not be a big deal.  When toner does run out, you'll end up spending about $70 a cartridge, so a replacement of all 4 (3 color and 1 black) will cost you between $200 and $300 depending on where you get the cartridges from.  What I recommend is that if you don't do a lot of color printing, just by a monochrome laser printer and supplement it with a cheap color ink jet.  Of course you have to consider whether or not you have room for two printers and also the cost of ink jet cartridges, which are not cheap either.  Now lets cover the good stuff and why I rated this 5-stars.  The printer is very fast and quiet.  It shoots out black & white pages very rapidly.  Of course color pages take a little longer, which you would expect, but are still reasonably fast.  Color print quality doesn't seem quite as good as some printers from other top printer manufacturers (such as EPSON and Canon), but it is adequate if your color printing requirements are not too precise.  Another thing I really like about Brother printers is that they include a FAX function.  Fax is a feature not as much needed these days, but there are times when it is needed and convenient.  Try to find a non-Brother printer with fax capability; I doubt you will.  The software install went easily and it wasn't too difficult to set up for wireless use.  You can use either USB or wireless.  The software is easy to use, but I did have difficulty trying to configure the printer to scan from the printer panel instead of the computer.  The scanning software on the computer is easy to use and it is easy to figure out how to scan letter or legal (or other sizes) and also not difficult to print on legal size.  For legal printing you do have to open a door on the front and feed the sheets in.  There is no paper tray for legal size, so this is not the ideal printer for printing lots of legal sized pages.  My older monochrome Brother laser could also handle legal scans and printing, but very complicated and difficult to set up.  It is fairly easy with this printer.  Overall, so far, I find this printer to be a big improvement over previous laser printers I have owned.  If I run into any problems later, I will update this review.  Note: I did not try the duplex scan, which seems like a good feature to have.

title: Elegant, Beautiful, Hand-Made Cards Have Applied “Gems” text: These PAPYRUS GEM CHRISTMAS TREE CHRISTMAS CARDS (Boxed with Gold Foil-Lined Red Envelopes, Gold Foil Seals; 8-Count) are hand-made--you can tell because each card varies slightly in the placement of the tree decorations. The colorful plastic 3D “gems” gently glow, and the glitter areas (especially at the tree base) sparkle like gold. These cards are standouts.

The red envelopes are lined with gold foil, and there are 8 gold hummingbird seals to decorate the envelope flaps. The message inside is “Celebrate the season and have a very merry Christmas”. There is room on the back of the message insert to write a short note if desired. Every detail of these cards is so carefully thought out, to make it all "just so".

Papyrus products are more expensive than Hallmark or American Greetings products, but I really love the elegant Papyrus designs. I think they're worth the extra cost whenever you want a really special card or gift wrap for someone.

title: Perfect for coaches!! text: Ordered for my college grad. who’s taken a position as a coach at a major university! At such a young age to be in such a big role- she must be organized and on top of her game in every aspect.. Being in charge of the women’s soccer team- she’s responsible for drills, workouts, trainings.. both during season and not. This accordion file allows her to keep a specific file of hardcopies pertaining to any and all designed drills, exercises, plays, etc. With 24+ slots it includes the individual spaces to separate offense, defense, and keeper position info. This file system is great in its ability to grow with ones need yet, without a load its amazingly small considering how much it can hold.

When open and in use.. this has a sturdy ability to stay upright giving easy access. Tabs allow user to create any system they choose and includes use of premade tabs or DIY for your own system.. any way it’s done these have solid dividers to keep content organized! Adjustable bungee elastic is a main component in why this works so well.. it will securely accommodate however big/small the load is- and this cord gives a snug and personal fit making it easy to transport without issues! Great perk for those who need to take their work home from the office with them..

Color choice just equates to the front see thru panel and the color that’s present behind it. The interior uses a combo of the x3 color options to help show division of individual pockets. For under $15 this is a nicely built and capable of doing the job at hand. This is actually x2 we’ve ordered by this maker- daughter uses smaller version to carry her players personal medical info. traveling to away events.. something worthy to have on hand in a medical emergency. The uses are endless if need of an organized system to keep physical papers arises.
Hoping this info. helps your decision- stay safe!

title: Ink runs out ASAP
text: This is the first (and last) time I'll use anything but genuine HP printer cartridges. The first color cartridge printed a half-dozen sheets of photo paper and was suddenly showing that it was "low on ink." I cleaned the printer and printed two more sheets, and yes, the message was correct: the color was already running out! Since the return time period is expired, I'm stuck with poor products, so might as well use them up, but I am extremely disappointed with cartridges that were touted as being almost identical in quality to HP. NOT! The shipping time and packaging were just fine; no complaints on either count, and had I used the cartridges within the return time of approx. 3 months, other reviews indicate that the seller would have been great to work with on a return or replacement.

title: Sticks stuff to things and things to stuff and things to things and stuff to stuff
text: If you want it stuck right there, and you want to be able to remove it later, and what you're sticking and where you're sticking it have smooth surfaces, this is what you need. It'll come off plastic and glass clean. Don't use too big of a piece, or you might break something trying to remove it. For instance, for those of you who know how heavy an XBox One X is, I can now lift the console by the USB hub I've attached to the top of it. But, if I pull up one edge hard enough, I can peel the hub off without leaving a trace. Although after a year or so, I'm sure it would leave a noticeable clean spot. Good for plastic and glass. Might work with metal, but I haven't tried it yet. And please, put it in a baggy or a storage box so it won't get all hairy.

title: Gets the Message Across text: Certain members of my family like their beauty sleep and they do not want to be woken up in the middle of a restful nap. If one or both dogs are with said person, the situation is even worse because even a quiet opening of the door can get the dogs barking and wake them up in the process. To help resolve this problem, I got a set of these Door Hangers, from CROWATTS.

There are several varieties of from which to select with this brand. I went with the one that was most practical for me: Do Not Disturb/Please Knock. I got the ones with the blue color and dessert, since they have a tropical look which fits the theme of our house. At first glance, it looks like a cocktail and pool in the background but closer examination proves otherwise.

What stands out most with these door hangers is their construction. You get a set of four and they are heavy- duty, thicker than most, with a vinyl- like feel. They won’t tear and are waterproof. You just slip them on a doorknob or door handle and you’re all set. There is a slit in the opening, too, to make it possible to fit them on most any door handle, but a doorknob seems to be where they fit best.

With the Do Not Disturb clearly on display, we can cut back on accidental room entries and the irritation of being woken up too soon from a good nap or deep sleep. These door hangers have more practical use than I first thought and I predict they will continue to make a difference for many months to come. I’m most impressed with the construction and this fact alone earns this product a solid recommendation.

title: I have been using Peter Pauper Compact Address Books for YEARS....This is my FOURTH one text: I bought the CELESTIAL style, very pretty, for last about four years (I tend to get a new one about once a year, just because of address changes, additions, deletions and I like a NEW one :-)).

I wanted the SAME style, just different design for a change. So....here are my thoughts re the FEATHERS one.

PROS:

PRICE - usually 8.99, just got this on sale here for 6.99 so a plus, but DEFINITELY worth the 8.99!

LOOK - I LOVE the subdued, but slightly glossy look! No, it's not a BRIGHT design, but I love the look and the slight glisten to it.

QUALITY - I was already used to this style having the Celestial which is like this, just different color and tab color, for years. LOVE the quality. Wonderful, sturdy hardback cover, page thickness is FINE for me and LOVE the tabs.

SIZE - GREAT size to drop in your bag. I have a LARGE Peter Pauper one to keep on my desk at home.
This small one gives me plenty of room for the info I need, like ems or phone numbers. The larger one is great to add things like birthdays, addresses with PLENTY of room left over.

title: I got a great deal for a used Uplift reclaimed-wood standing-desk for $350 ... text: This perfectly fits my Uplift 30x60 desk.
I got a great deal for a used Uplift reclaimed-wood standing-desk for $350 with all the bells and whistles/accessories added of a $1400 brand new Uplift desk.
Yet I did not think of protecting this great desk deal. I spilled hot tea on it one night, quickly cleaned it up over a minute, yet didnt realize some tea prob got through the cracks in the panels of wood and the next night realized the wood had expanded/warped upwards so much in those areas.
I bought this to protect against future tea spills. and it looks like it will do the job.
One side is very clear (but feels stickier, so I assume this should be the bottom), and one side is more patterned/blurry (feels very plasticy so easier to slide things like cups, etc on your desk, so i assume this should be the top).
The reclaimed wood pattern is a tiny bit muffled/blurred but still looks great (the muffled side's pattern is kinda nice too since you don't have to worry about keeping it scratch-free/spotless). Note: there was a small 'streak' on the clear side of the desk like a few other reviewers mentioned. Didnt bother me since the clear side is going to be hidden under the muffled side if you choose to make the muffled side the top.
I wonder if its always meant to be placed that way.

Quick tip for a tea spilling incident like mine: I was able to flatten the raised/warped portions of the panels of wood where the tea spilled by placing ten 10 lb weights on top of it in varying locations of the panels over 4 days and finally got the desk where its mostly flat/even across the surface again. (so basically 100lbs total focused on one area, just need a few sheets of paper placed under the weights so the weights don't dent the wood at the hard edges of the weights).

title: A nifty way to keep paperwork tidy.
text: Great little system. Keeps the paper mess more organized. Only issue is with storage capacity; if you have a lot of paper in one particular tray, the sturdiness of the stack becomes wobbly. The tray walls have raised 3-D tabs that fit into each other as they stack. Too much paper pushes the tab of the overfilled tray out of the tray tab above. You have room for 1.5”-2” worth of paper in each tray. After that, start a second tray for that topic. They actually send you an abundance of trays. Lol!

title: Math Workshop 5 text: I am a homeschool mom, so I am often on the lookout for educational helps. This workbook is allowed to be reproduced in the classroom setting. The “workshop” set up is intended for classroom group work done through stations.
Each section has a an essential question, a math warm-up, a mini-lesson, “math talk” (questions to ask about solving problems), and a journaling question. You then have guided math questions and worksheets- one worksheet is recommended, one is on level but branching out a bit, and one worksheet is enrichment. All answers are in the back of the workbook.
As a homeschooler, this could be used as enrichment. You could simply take the worksheets or hands on activities and use those to supplement curriculum you’re already using. You could also use the entire model as complete curriculum. The workshop model would work just fine for one kid just like it would for 20. It is going to be pretty teacher intensive and they aren’t going to be able to complete this as a curriculum completely independently. You would still need to give the mini-lessons. But some kids do better with having someone show them and walk through it with them. You can also fold the entire thing in with your current curriculum, using this to beef up a curriculum that has a few more holes.
This book covers:
Operations (PEMDAS) and Algebraic Thinking
Number Operations in Base Ten
Number and Operations of Fractions
Measurement and Data
Geometry
There are also a few extras in the back for games you could play for a number of different skills.

title: Moleskine Passions Recipe Journal text: The Moleskine Passions Recipe Journal is a well made diary sized (5"x8¼") notebook printed on medium/light weight acid free paper with 240 total pages. It contains sections for most typical areas of cooking; Appetizers, First Course, Main Dishes, Deserts, etc. plus several unlabeled sections for the owner to personalize. In addition there are weight, measure and temperature conversion charts, produce and fruit harvest/ripeness charts, food information charts and sections for notes, event or party planning. The cover is cleverly embossed with kitchen utensils and includes an elastic strap to keep the journal securely closed. Also included are three handy attached bookmarks and an expandable pocket in the back which contains the two sheets of stickers (for personalization) that come with the journal.

The pages for recording your recipes have limited space for writing, you'll need write carefully and small to fit most recipes on a page. The pages are not removable and pages cannot be added or moved around. The print in the book (charts, tables, etc.) is nearly microscopic. I found it very hard to read anything in the journal. As well the current and recent prices listed here on Amazon make this a very expensive and hard to justify choice.

title: Impressive
text: This was extremely difficult to find at 71 inches in all white so of course I snapped it up the minute I could get it.  The entire set up is very straight forward and not complicated which was a huge relief.  Be warned the parts are very heavy for the average person.  I'm glad it came in three boxes via FedEx because there would have been no way to get it up a flight of stairs if the entire thing had been pre-assembled.  The instructions were only slightly confusing when the legs were to be attached to the bottom of the table itself but overall it becomes immediately obvious once parts are all set out.  The holes for the electronic interface are a bit small and are only starter holes so it helps to have a good sized screw driver to get them all the way in.  I believe the interface to the electronic panel could have been a little more modern for the money spent.  But overall I'm completely impressed.  I originally had questioned how study the desk would be with a large monitor attached via vesa mount on an arm, but no issues there either.  The desk does not move or sway at all which is always a question with rising desks.  There is no platform on which to set a tower which is the only thing I would suggest to add in the future.  The legs are not exactly a white, but an off color of a gray/white mix but it still looks very pretty and doesn't clash with other colors.

title: Easy set up, great price, very versatile and effective text: Wanted a multi-function that would work wirelessly for the several computers and smart phones at home. Setting up the the printer on WiFi was a snap. It recognized the SSID right away and I just had to enter the password. Every computer and smart phone then recognized the printer wirelessly right away. We've tested by printing from two computers and one phone. Flawless!

The scan function works great as does the document feeder, which is really helpful for scans as you do not have to take the time to place your document(s) directly on the platen, or remove it (them). The little LCD screen is really easy to use for scanning, which is quick and of good quality. The color touch screen is bright and the icons are easy to read and easy to use.

The print and scan quality are excellent. I didn't need it to be top of the line quality, but it sure is close. The print is a little light, but other users have said that this makes the MFC870 easy on ink use.

For under $100, this little multifunction is a super deal. It is by far the best ink-jet I've ever owned and the well-designed multifunction capabilities make it the most versatile too.

The 100-count paper tray is I suppose a bit of a downside. But, if you only print 100 pages every couple of weeks like we do, it's hardly noticeable.

This is the first Brother printer I've ever owned. Sure glad I got it. :)

title: Great “on the go” notebook for us listmakers out there!! text: Loving this perfect little notebook.. and it’s ability to serve a multitude of uses!! When saying “little” that translates to a perfect size! Note: it is smaller then 8x11 sheet of paper (standard size) but, big enough in size for a page to hold real content! Refer to the Goldilocks scale- not too big, not too small.. but, rather right in the sweet spot of a happy medium- it’s just right!!

I love this slides perfectly into purse, backpack, or even the computer sleeve itself- being made smaller then, standard size notebook.. it eliminates the taking of extra space, especially if a purse is not that big. I was needing something to travel easy -I’m a list maker!! In full swing of corona quarantine and a mom of 4, theres just too many things i must keep track of- So, keeping a “mom Bible“ lets me scribble down any assignment info., due dates, Rx pick up reminders.. lists we may need to survive.. you get the idea! (yes! We can add info to phone but, I always start lists and then, never remember where I stored them on my dang device!!)

This hardcover notebook is sturdy which also, not only helps keep pages/content safe.. but, provides a solid writing surface. I LOVE the ribbon page markers and connected band to keep book tightly closed- so, only thing missing was a small pocket. I solved this issue by placing an add-in adhesive pocket directly on the inside cover.
Ordered in royal blue and TBH, it’s bright enough to find when Ive set it down 100 different places!! No, pages aren't lined but, rather dot lined, which is nice to keep one from writing “uphill..” Yet, you can still use to create a sketch if desired.. As a first time user of a dotted line system, I REALY like it! (waiting with kids, I kept them busy with just x1 page of the handy dandy notebook and pencil, to play connect 4 box game- Ha! surprise bonus!!)

This is sleek and nice enough to become anyone’s journal or, appropriate business notebook- the uses are endless and so, are colors to choose from.. For those who want, they even offer blank or, fully lined pages. Truly, covers all the bases... you can’t go wrong with this!!
Would be awesome if a notebook was sold offering all three paper styles… Blank/dot/line!! That would be amazing-
Hope this info. Helps.. feel free to let me know!

title: Not worth the price
text: I love the fact that these are geared towards left handed people. But they are not worth the price. I ordered 3 because I am going back to college in my adult life.  I always hated the binding on "normal" notebooks hurting when I write. When you finish writing on the front and flip to the back of the paper, the binding is on the left again. So what do you do, not write on the back of the paper. If you flip the notebook upside down to keep the binding on the right, now the back of the paper is upside down. For me it will just have to work since I don't have to turn papers in. But if a student needs to actually turn in the paper, it's not ok. The idea is good. But not for me. If you are a lefty, look for a notebook with no binder. It also would have been nice to pick what colors I received.  Overall, great concept. But I would not buy again.

title: Excellent Quality, Great Price Works As Good As Or Better Than Originals text: When I got my Pixma TS8220 printer from Canon, I was not expecting to like it as much as I have. I have always been an HP girl. The colors were truer and the quality better. Well, not anymore. I have often printed something out on my HP 8710 only to have to print it out on my Canon for much better quality when doing reference photos for paintings or drawings. I ran out of ink. Let's see what happened.

WHAT ARE THESE LIKE?
These come just like other ink cartridges-each in plastic with an orange guard on the ink opening to protect it. It also comes with a foam wedge in the lever to keep it from breaking- nice touch. The sets of these are a full set minus the photo blue, which I tend to reserve for only a few photos now and then.

HOW DID THESE WORK?
I found myself having a problem with my large black cartridge- stripes and failure everywhere! Then I opened up the cartridge from this set and it is BEAUTIFUL. The black is even nicer than the original black that came with this set. This is the 2nd color I have replaced from this set and I am thrilled at how nicely they work.

PRINT QUALITY
I am impressed at how much nicer this printer and ink refills print my reference photos for art. It is important to have a reasonably balanced color reference. My HP just was not doing it for me and this printer with these cartridges have been wonderful.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Although this does not come with photo blue, the price for two sets of ink of each of the other colors is an excellent price. The quality is great, no conflicts, I will buy these again for sure if the price stays as nice.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I love my printer and am very happy to have these reasonable cartridges to use in it. HP is over priced and the quality just isn't like it used to be in my experience as far as color inkjets go.

title: Vintage-looking journal with a few "dirty" pages and cheaply dyed leather; nice design text: I ordered their [[ASIN:B07PZVN2WN tree journal]] and was not happy with it. However, this journal is cleaner and the paper whiter. It is vintage-looking but not too dirty and worn that it offends my senses.

As is typical of a leather-bound journal, the paper is not replaceable. Writing on the paper with pen or pencil works well. A few pages have smudges on them and I did see some thread or lint between some pages. The underside of the leather is poorly dyed looking as if it is dirty and does appear to have fingerprints dyed in the back of the journal. I do not care for those fingerprints. The tie is just a string of leather and not set in a way that makes it intuitive to tie the book shut. The embossing on the outside is very attractive, however.

There are five sections that are "stitched" into the book. Each section has a centerfold string.

The six photos show the following in order:

1 - The attractive stitching on the binding and the outer leather embossing.

2 - The front of the journal.

3 - The back of the journal.

4 - The blotchy spots found on some pages pages.

5 - The front inside leather cover and blotchy dye work.

6 - The back inside leather cover and blotchy dye work with fingerprint stains.

In summary, they succeeded in making this look dirty vintage and handmade from scrap. The exterior embossing of a dragon design is super attractive and so is the binder stitching. The leather is cheap and the paper is sometimes blotchy with occasional pieces of lint. This is definitely better than the [[ASIN:B07PZVN2WN tree journal]] I ordered from them. Since the intention here is to look vintage, I would say they succeeded. I would not expect to pay more than $18 - $20 for this in its current condition. It has "found in the attic" sort of vibe to it.

title: Excellent product, but seems a bit bulky and pricey. text: Now, the title is coming from someone new to the world of binding machines. My fiancee is a 4th-grade math teacher, so I thought this would be of great assistance to her. I didn't know what to expect, and was a little dumbfounded when I first set it up, but then I realized just how easy it was.

You can only put 20 sheets of paper at a time to punch the holes in, but it works flawlessly. The actual binding mechanism left me a bit hesitant at first, as I thought it was too easy and there was something I was doing wrong. Once the machine took over, however, my fears were tossed at sea.

So why the one less star? Perhaps it's just me, but it seems a bit heavy and pricey for just what it does. Again, I'm no binding machine expert, and I'm sure the electronic version is far superior to the manual, but $275 is a bit much considering it only punches 20 pages at at time, and 26 pounds seems overwhelming, especially since it's electronic.

The machine is going to stay in the house for years to come, or as long as someone stays a teacher, and has already served its purpose in the short time that we've had it.
